item.title: Itâ€™s Time
item.author: Devin Vassell
item.description: Thereâ€™s still so much more that I have left to prove. Iâ€™ll always have that mindset.
item.content:encoded:
Every hooper got that one guy from their hometown that made them fall in love with the game.

Everybody got that guy.

For me? That was Lou Will.

Lou went to South Gwinnett, so when I was growing up, all I heard was story after story about Lou Williams.

He was nice, nice. To this day heâ€™s one of my favorite players.

They used to start off pretty much every game with a lob play to Lou. Heâ€™d get an early look at the rim and score. Right out the gate.Â

The crowd would already be standing in the bleachers before the ball dropped through the hoop. Everybody had seen it happen enough times to know it was going in. Iâ€™ll never forget how the gym would go crazy for like the whole game.

And Lou? He would be killing.

I just wanted that moment, you know? People on they feet, screaming, just going crazy for a high school kid.

Back home in the driveway, Iâ€™d be practicing moves. I took pieces out of a lot of peopleâ€™s games. I was skinny â€” I was thin and long â€” so everybody was like, â€œYo, youâ€™re like KD.â€ I always kind of watched KD to see how he came into his shots, trying to analyze some of the moves that he did.

Whatâ€™s KD doing? Oh, howâ€™d he do that spin? Alright. Alright. Let me go try that outside.Â

Thatâ€™s kind of how it was for me. As I got older, I watched more and more people, just trying to study them â€” observe their specific styles. I watched Devin Booker. I watched Paul George. I studied Kawhi on defense. I watched a bunch of Jrue Holiday. And OF COURSE I watched LeBron. Thatâ€™s a given.Â Â

I probably looked crazy to the people in the cars that would drive down my block, eyes closed, acting like Iâ€™m somebody else, shooting fadeaways.Â

My dream was that when I got out of Gwinnett, Georgia, people would be saying, â€œMan, back in the day? That Devin Vassell kid was crazy!â€

My dream was that people would pack out my high school games. Standing room only. And I thought Iâ€™d be one and done, going almost straight to the league. Buuut, if Iâ€™m telling the truth, it wasnâ€™t really like that. Like at all.

You wanna know how my first big high school game went?

They were booing me.

Record scratch, freeze-frame. â€œYouâ€™re probably wondering how I got here.â€

I donâ€™t mean they were booing the team or our fans or something like that.Â

They were booing ME, specifically.

It was definitely a movie moment. Just not the one I had imagined.

It was more like the movies where the hero is in some crazy situation, and itâ€™s like, Record scratch, freeze-frame. â€œYouâ€™re probably wondering how I got here.â€

Let me rewind a bit.

My dad had played college ball back in the day, and my brother was so much older that he was already playing basketball by the time I was born, so it wasnâ€™t long before one of them put a ball in my hands.Â

I just fell in love with the game, instantly. Really as soon as I can remember.

Me and my dad spent a lot of time in the gym together when I was growing up. But we started out just going to parks with my ball. I used to go to Collins Hill Park over by the high school over there, and Peachtree Ridge Park, which was part of my high school. Thereâ€™s a lot more parks in Gwinnett, too. Bogan Park. Listen, I could go on and on about some parks.

But Iâ€™ll never forget being outside with my dad, me running around doing moves in some like entry-level Nikes. I think they were Roshes. Him catching the rebounds and whipping the ball back to me as the sun went down.Â

And this was all after heâ€™d been at work all day. As soon as he came through the door, Iâ€™d be like, â€œAlright, come on, come on. Letâ€™s go, letâ€™s go.â€ And heâ€™d be all like, â€œIâ€™m tired, but all right. Iâ€™m going to do it. Iâ€™m going to do it.â€

Didnâ€™t even have no real basketball shoes yet, just out there hooping in the dark with my dad.

As early as elementary school, when I told adults what I wanted to be when I grew up, theyâ€™d make sure to tell me that most people donâ€™t make it to the NBA. Theyâ€™d always be like, â€œWhatâ€™s your backup option?â€

I remember the first time my dream was tested.

I was in middle school, and it was my seventh-grade year. The middle school is seventh and eighth grade, so I was basically trying out for the eighth grade team.

Weâ€™re going through the tryouts, and Iâ€™m killing all the drills, killing everybody in front of me.Â

Iâ€™m like, Oh, Iâ€™m set.Â

After tryouts, the first roster gets released. I made that cut, so Iâ€™m like, Oh, yeah. I know Iâ€™m straight.

Next day, the second roster gets posted. I went to look, and my name wasnâ€™t on there. My first thought was literally that it was a mistake. I went to talk to the coach thinking, Thereâ€™s no way my nameâ€™s not on there. But sure enough, theyâ€™re like, â€œYeah, sorry. We just donâ€™t think that you have the ability to make the team this year.â€

And the kicker: â€œBut you can be a manager.â€

Iâ€™d love to say that I took it really well. But Iâ€™d have to have been some extremely mature seventh grader.

I said, â€œNah, Iâ€™m straight,â€ and walked out of that gym so quick. I had a rolling chair in my room, and there was probably about three seconds between me storming through the front door of my house and me putting that chair through the wall. I left a huge hole. Then I went stomping around the neighborhood.Â

I was like, Nah, there is no way. There is no way I didnâ€™t make this team.

Honestly, it brought down my confidence a lot.

And if it wasnâ€™t bad enough that I didnâ€™t make the team, the assistant coach was also my social studies teacher. So I had to see this man every day after that!!! Heâ€™s asking the class about British parliament or whatever and Iâ€™m just steaming.

I finished out the school year, and that summer, I transferred schools. I went to our rival school.

When I was a sophomore at Peachtree Ridge High, and my first varsity game came against those kids at my old school whoâ€™d made the team ahead of me just a few years before, I was a skinny kid with a point to prove.

But as soon as I walk in the gym, Iâ€™m already sick to my stomach. Iâ€™m thinking, Iâ€™m finally here. Iâ€™m in front of all these people that knew me at my old middle schools.

And when I came out of the tunnel, everybody started booing.

Like, â€œBoo, Devin!â€Â

Oh.

That was my reaction. â€œOh.â€

Coach says, â€œAlright, Devin, itâ€™s time for you to go in,â€ and my heart starts pounding.

I get in the game, and Iâ€™m playing my role. Whole time, the crowd straight trashing me. Just talking a whole bunch of mess.

We come down the court, and I spot up in the corner. They pass the ball to me.

The clank of a brick means you at least got close. You hit the rim. But I didnâ€™t even do that. I airballed in front of all those people who knew me from before and were waiting for me to fail.

I said, â€œOh, no. Oh, no.â€

When I came out of the tunnel, everybody started booing.

A couple of minutes later, my rotation was still playing. The crowd still talking mess.Â

I get it again, same corner. Another air ball.

Iâ€™m thinking, Oh no, get me out of here, Coach.

We ended up winning the game, but I bombed hard. I donâ€™t think I even attempted to shoot the rest of that game.

But after that year, every single time we played them, it was wraps for them. I was good after that. I just needed to shake off the nerves.

I think everybody whoâ€™s ever tried to be really great at something has a story like that. They had a game where they just ... werenâ€™t good. I know I probably have a few more of those moments to look forward to in my NBA career.

But those moments are learning opportunities. I know that no matter what exactly is ahead of me, there are going to be ups and there are going to be downs, both on and off the court.

Iâ€™ve already dealt with some of that. Some of the biggest challenges Iâ€™ve faced, people donâ€™t even know about.

When I was around sixth and seventh grade, my family was going through some things. I donâ€™t like to talk too much about whatâ€™s going on in my private life. I keep everything in-house, especially when it comes to family stuff.

But one of the greatest challenges Iâ€™ve faced in my life was back then, when my mom had been having severe back issues and had to go through surgeries and stuff like that. She had been a nurse up to that point and used to work long hours, but she couldnâ€™t work anymore and had to go on disability.Â

Just seeing her sometimes not feeling her best was very tough on me mentally as a kid. Maybe more than I even realized.

Seeing that it wasnâ€™t as easy for her to do some stuff anymore, like getting out of the car, or just walking around â€” when that kind of thing happens to someone thatâ€™s very important in your life, it can take a toll.

But my mom is one of the strongest people on the planet, and with her being as strong as she is, it just became motivation for me. It was motivation for us all, as a family.

Iâ€™m lucky to be close with both of my parents, and theyâ€™ve really tried to prepare me for everything thatâ€™s ahead of me. Weâ€™ve had a lot of talks, but mainly their message has been to stay grounded. They told me, â€œBe who you are, stay humble, and remember where you came from.â€

Iâ€™ll never forget those lessons.

And I wonâ€™t forget that no matter whether I won or lost, or when I didnâ€™t make the team, they never stopped believing in my dream.

Thereâ€™s still so much more that I have left to prove. Iâ€™ll always have that mindset. Thatâ€™s not going to go away, no matter the success, no matter whatâ€™s going on in my life.Â

I think that just growing up my whole life and not being ranked, not getting some of the credit or recognition I feel like I deserved, it definitely stays with me.

But it also makes this moment â€” right now, as I prepare for draft night â€” that much more of a blessing.Â

Itâ€™s a blessing to be where Iâ€™m at, and Iâ€™ll never take that for granted.

Alright, one last story. March 2019, ACC tournament quarterfinals. FSU vs. Virginia Tech.

Weâ€™re down three, with about seven seconds left in the game.

I was on a hot streak and had made three of five three-pointers.Â

Everybody had been telling me, â€œYouâ€™re hot, youâ€™re hot. Keep shooting if you get open.â€Â

So now, weâ€™re in the huddle. A play is called. Iâ€™m in the game, but the play isnâ€™t just for me â€” there are options. Trent Forrest was inbounding, and there was somebody wide open, right next to him.Â

But when we came out the huddle, I said, â€œBro, listen, if you pass it to me, Iâ€™m shooting it.â€Â

He looked at me. I said, â€œIf you pass it to me, Iâ€™m shooting it. So take it for what you want.â€

And he was just like, â€œAlright.â€

So, Trent gets up to the line, and he looks. He sees me come up the screen and just darts it to me.

I come off of a flare screen to the corner and hit the three, with a hand in the face.Â

I looked back at Trent and said, â€œWell, I told you.â€

We ended up winning in overtime. And the craziest thing about it all wasnâ€™t even the hot streak I went on that night. It was that they came to the freshman.

They came to a freshman for that. Itâ€™s just the fact that they had that much confidence in me. Not only the coaches, but my teammates.Â

It was huge. It meant everything.

When I was younger, my goal was always to be one and done, always. Elementary school, I was like Yeah, Iâ€™m going to be at the McDonald's game. One and done. Itâ€™s wraps.Â

Then when I got offered by Florida State they told me that Iâ€™d probably have to redshirt my first year. So all that went out the window. But I just told myself, I said, Iâ€™m going to go to Florida State for two years. Iâ€™ll be there for two years, and then Iâ€™m gone.

I kept that to myself. I told my parents, and my close friends, and that was it.Â

But I stayed in my role and didnâ€™t step on nobodyâ€™s toes â€” and I just kept working.

People are gonna tell you that youâ€™re not gonna make it because you might not be the biggest. You might not be the fastest. You might not be the strongest. They might even want you to be the team manager.

But it doesnâ€™t matter if you put in the work.

I just put it in the work and stuck to my dream.

Everything Iâ€™ve ever done, every experience Iâ€™ve ever had, every challenge Iâ€™ve ever faced, has led me to this moment.Â

And as I sit here writing this, in my blue 2020 NBA Draft Combine polo shirt, I want to remember it all.

When my sophomore year at FSU finally came around, I said to myself, Well, you said you were only going to be here for two.Â

This is two.Â

Itâ€™s time.

item.title: Nine Things I Want PacersÂ Fans to Know About Me
item.author: Cassius Stanley
item.description: Iâ€™m here, first and foremost, because basketball is what I live and breathe.
item.keywords: NBA Draft,Duke University,Duke Blue Devils,basketball,cassius stanley,nba,indiana,Indiana Pacers
item.content:encoded:
To the city of Indianapolis, and to Pacers fans everywhereâ€¦..Â

Thank you so much for the warm welcome, for real. I read ALL of your messages last night â€” yâ€™all being excited has me excited.

Itâ€™s been a pretty wild journey for me to get to this pointâ€¦. and it kind of feels like one chapter is coming to a close now, while this other one is just beginning. And so I thought it might be a cool idea to write a few things down â€” just to mark the moment, in a way, and show my gratitude.Â

And maybe to help you get to know your 2020 Draft Pick a little bit.

Hereâ€™s a few thoughts on where Iâ€™m at, and what Iâ€™m about:

(1) I love sports.Â

No, I donâ€™t think you understand: I love sports. Iâ€™m obsessed with sports. Likeâ€¦.. Iâ€™m not one of these dudes who just had a growth spurt, realized he was 6' 6" or whatever, and then decided to give hooping a try.

Iâ€™m here, first and foremost, because basketball is what I live and breathe.

(2) One play Iâ€™m always proud of, that I think reflects who I am as a player, was in my junior year of high school â€” state semifinals.

So weâ€™re one game away from the California state championship, and weâ€™re down late. Itâ€™s all coming down to the final play. And letâ€™s be honest: a lot of people here are probably expecting me to tell a story about how I hit some game-winning shot.Â

But thatâ€™s not the case.

Nah. See, we had me on our team, and I was one of our leaders for sure â€” but we also had this guy Duane Washington, whoâ€™s a really good player (heâ€™s at Ohio State now). And my mentality in that moment was, listen: Iâ€™m always ready to take the big shot. But my top priority? Itâ€™s to make the winning play. And the way we figured it, drawing it up, with my athleticism and being able to see over the defense and whatnot, we were going to run a play with me as the full-court inbound passer, and my role was to hit Duane in the perfect spot for him to get in space for a bucket.

Basically the Grant Hill to Christian Laettner Play, right?? But I actually think ours was harder, because Duane was double-teamed. And I had to basically drop a dime, right in his hands, over two defenders. (You know what, maybe it was more like Kyler to D-Hop.) Anyway â€” I hit that pass, Duane hit his shot, we tied it up, won in 2OT, and went on to a state title.

Iâ€™m always ready to take the big shot. But my top priority? Itâ€™s to make the winning play.

(3) I know my history.Â

If you think Iâ€™m too young to be referencing Grant Hill to Christian Laettner â€” youâ€™re right. That play happened seven years before I was born. But at the same time, a classic like that, itâ€™s kind of a good way for me to show you what Iâ€™m about. Because Iâ€™m all about respecting the classics. Iâ€™m all about learning from my OGs.

I grew up being the type of kid whose idea of a fun night could easily just be watching the replay of an old NBA game â€” and Iâ€™m still that way. The other night, I was watching some random Bulls vs. Hawks matchup from the late 1980sâ€¦. and it blew me away. Of course, real heads, they already know why: late â€™80s Bulls vs. Hawks meansÂ Michael vs. Dominique.

It was unbelievable. Those dudes were at the absolute peak of their powers, and they just went at it, tip to buzzer.

It was like the type of battles youâ€™d have with your friends in the driveway, growing up â€” when itâ€™s first to 21, youâ€™re going shot for shot, and itâ€™s WAR. Only this was on that NBA stage. Levels and levels to greatness.

(4) Actually, while Iâ€™ve got this platform, I have a hot take for you all.Â

Last Dance era Mike? He was nice. I mean, he was more than nice â€” late-â€™90s Mike is about as iconic as it gets. But still Iâ€™ll tell you what: late-â€™80s MJ?? Young, wiry Mike?? That might be my favorite version of the man. That might be the GOATâ€™s GOAT era.

Itâ€™s crazy, the stuff that Michael was pulling off. One thing I noticed is how efficient he was with the ball. Sometimes it would be two dribbles to his spot and then elevation. Or it would be three dribbles, direct to the rim. Maybe one quick in-and-out, or one crossover, max â€” but even those moves, every time, you could tell he was setting up his finish.

Late-â€™80s MJ?? Young, wiry Mike?? That might be my favorite version of the man.

And thatâ€™s been a really big lesson for me, from watching Michael in his younger years, that Iâ€™m trying to emulate: A lot of people, they see one scouting report on you, and they write you off as all flash. â€œJust an athlete.â€ But I think Iâ€™m going to be able to show people that athleticism like I have can be a weapon in surprising ways. It can be something that helps with efficiency on both ends of the court.

(5) Thereâ€™s this rumor going around that I started dunking in ninth grade â€” but itâ€™s not true.

I started dunking in sixth grade.Â

Well, technically it was the summer before seventh grade. A couple of days before orientation.Â

I think it was a situation where, like, they needed a few volunteers to pop into school that day to help set things up. So I was hanging around the gym doing my volunteer thing, Iâ€™m in my Sierra Canyon â€œuniformâ€ â€” collared shirt + khaki shorts (no board shorts) + Vans â€” and of course you know thereâ€™s a ball out. And itâ€™s a bunch of us just messing around.

O.K. so backtrack for one second: I had this thing, I donâ€™t even know how or why it started, where I was just like â€” one of my big goals was to dunk before I started middle school. I wanted that so bad. So for all of sixth grade, and the summer before seventh grade, that had been one of the main things Iâ€™d get up to. Trying and trying to dunk. But pretty much all my tries up to that point were ending the same: clank, in and out, almost like an invisible hand was stuffing me at the rim. Like I was a few inches short, but I might as well have been a few feet short. It was a struggle.

Until it wasnâ€™t.Â

I have no idea what was different about that day. Maybe I grew overnight, or I had a little extra cereal for breakfast, orâ€¦.. I donâ€™t know. All I know is, it was this bunch of us in the gym hanging out, I picked up the ball and I hit my stride, and then â€” BAM.

O.K. â€” so it wasnâ€™t Zach LaVine in the Dunk Contest or anything. But in my head?? In my head it was like a 97, easy. Maybe a 98. In my head it was clean.

Itâ€™s funny, people are always asking me for advice on how to dunk better. Or jump higher. How to add those inches to their vertical. And itâ€™s just likeâ€¦.. have you ever been in a math class, and the teacher is writing some complex equation on the board, and your brain's going,Â Excuse me? WHAT?? Like you know you did the homework and everything, and youâ€™re not bad at math, but, nah. No way. That thing on the board canâ€™t be real. It makes zero sense. And then you turn to your right and the kid at the next deskâ€¦.. he hasnâ€™t just already finished it. Heâ€™s obliterated it. And youâ€™re like, â€œBro â€” howâ€™d you do that?? Howâ€™d you solve that equation??â€ And he tells you, like, â€œI canâ€™t really explain it. Honestly I just kind of did it, you know? It was easy.â€

Alright well thatâ€™s like me and dunking. For most people, with dunking, itâ€™s like they see a bunch of confusing numbers on the board and it will never make sense.

For me? Itâ€™s easy.

I just kind of obliterate it.

I just dunk.

(6) Oh yeah and then one other funny thing about that.

My mom is an insane athlete. Actually, check that â€” she was a heptathlete. For those who donâ€™t know the heptathlon, itâ€™s seven events: hurdles, high jump, shot put, 200m sprint, long jump, javelin, and 800m run. Itâ€™s beyond legit. And like I said, my mom was insane. She was an All-America at UCLA, and competed at a world-class level. Itâ€™s wild. My mom was a legend in the game.

And then my dad is a sports agent. And I love my dad to death â€” I could spend hours bragging about him, and heâ€™s a legend in his own game, for sure. But I wonâ€™t lie: He couldnâ€™t jump over a piece of paper.

So itâ€™s just kind of hilarious, because, likeâ€¦.. it doesnâ€™t take a genius to see that I got my jumping ability, and my athleticism in general, from my mom. But for whatever reason, I think because people have all of these gender biases, itâ€™s like they canâ€™t wrap their heads around that. So people are always looking at my dad â€” who is about 6' 1" and dresses like a DAD, if you know what I mean â€” and theyâ€™re always like, â€œHuh. So, what, did your dadâ€¦.. he play in the league? Or he play college ball? Orâ€¦..â€ And itâ€™s like, ha. No!! Canâ€™t jump, canâ€™t hoop. Thanks for asking.

Meanwhile, my mom was on the damn ALL AMERICA squad â€” and no one ever asks me a thing.

Check your bias, people!!!!!

And Mom, thanks for the hops.

(7) Iâ€™m proud of my Los Angeles roots.

I think at this point in our history, the proof is just in the names.Â

The LA-area roll call is deep: Russ. Harden. DeMar. Taurasi. Lonzo. The Holiday Bros. Jordin Canada. Zach LaVine. Paul George. OGs like Baron. Cheryl and Reggie. Tyson Chandler. Lisa Leslie. Paul Pierce. Cynthia Cooper. Gil. Nick Young. And then you have new blood like myself, Onyeka, LaMelo, and it goes on. Plus plenty of talent coming up behind us, in the high school and college ranks. (Shoutout to my guy Josh Christopher over at Arizona State. Remember the name.)

And whether itâ€™s training together, or crossing paths and building relationships in Drew League, or helping out the generation behind you, the bonds that stay holding LA basketball together are real. For example, and I wonâ€™t speak on this too much because I know he doesnâ€™t do it for the attention, but, manâ€¦.. would I be in the spot Iâ€™m in right now, having just gotten drafted to the league, if Russ hadnâ€™t taken me under his wing? If he hadnâ€™t gone out of his way to mentor me, and train with me, and look out for me? I donâ€™t know.

And thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m so grateful, and so proud to be a part of this lineage.Â

And itâ€™s why I expect a lot out of myself â€” both to pay it forward when itâ€™s my turn, and to play a type of basketball that might make me worthy of waving the flag for our city.

(8) Probably the thing thatâ€™s helped me most to get through this Draft process â€” itâ€™s a piece of advice I got from Coach K.Â

What happened wasâ€¦.. well, itâ€™s interesting.

After I jumped 44 inches at the combine, thatâ€™s a number thatâ€™s kind of stuck with me.Â

Everyone wants to bring it up. First thing Iâ€™ll get questions on in any interview. Third-highest combine number since 2000, and so on. And I think for a lot of people, a number like that, it can kind of be this albatross. They canâ€™t get free of that number, and then it sort of messes with their head. It can become this way to almost marginalize them: Youâ€™re just a jumper, or Youâ€™re a one dimensional player, or stuff like that.

But hereâ€™s why you go to Duke, man.

Hereâ€™s why you go to Duke: I already went through this once. Kind of insane, but itâ€™s true. Early on last fall at Duke, before Media Day in the preseason, I guess people found out that Iâ€™d broken Zionâ€™s maximum vertical record. I jumped 46 inches as a freshman. And everyoneâ€™s going crazy about it, right? So of course with Media Day coming, itâ€™s all anyone is going to ask me about.

Coach K, though, knowing that, and knowing I think how it could potentially have these negative effects on me, he took me aside. And the line Iâ€™ll never forget that he said to me is, he just goes â€” â€œCassius, thatâ€™s not an empty number.â€ And basically what Coach meant by that is, â€œ46â€.... thatâ€™s not some piece of trivia. Thatâ€™s not some show number. Itâ€™s not a â€œ12 guys in the gym and youâ€™re touching a stickâ€ number. Thatâ€™s a real number. Itâ€™s a productive number. â€œ46â€ means you can rebound like hell from the guard spot, when the other team thinks youâ€™re boxed out. â€œ46â€ means you can close out on a shooter that much faster, that much higher, that much more. â€œ46â€ means that where other guys are taking low-percentage floaters and tough-angle layups, youâ€™re playing above the rim at a high percentage. Youâ€™re playing the attack angles. Youâ€™re playing to win.

In other words: â€œ46,â€ â€œ44,â€ those arenâ€™t workout numbers â€” theyâ€™re basketball numbers.

And I donâ€™t jump to jump.

I jump to win basketball games.Â

(9) LETâ€™S GO, INDY.

Like I said at the top â€” this is an ending for me, but itâ€™s also a beginning. And I canâ€™t even tell you how excited I am for what this beginning represents. I canâ€™t even tell you how excited I am to become a part of this community, and to earn my spot on this Pacers roster.

And as soon as I started hearing from yâ€™all fans last nightâ€¦.. I knew I was in the right place.

I think thatâ€™s a good note to end this on.

Thanks for reading â€” and thanks for the opportunity of a lifetime.

Iâ€™m here to work and Iâ€™m here to win.

item.title: Mike Evans
item.author: Cameron Jordan, Mark Ingram II & Mike Evans
item.description: The epitome of consistency, a College Station legend and Harry Potterâ€™s biggest fan, Mike Evans drops by to chat with the fellas.
item.content:encoded: The epitome of consistency, a College Station legend and Harry Potterâ€™s biggest fan, Mike Evans drops by to chat with the fellas on Truss Levelz. We hear how Mike held up during the offseason. TLDR: Just fine. Then we go back to the beginning and hear about how he was supposed to be hooper until football interfered with that whole plan. Youâ€™ll hear who his best opponent in high was and how he chose Texas A&M. Life as an Aggie and the easy decision to go pro. He plays coy about catching passes this offseason with THE GOAT, TB12. But opens up about life and family, and yes, his unabiding love for Harry Potter. #wandlife. Mike reveals what house the Sorting Hat would place him in and how he would fare on the Quidditch pitch. He makes a strong case for why he would not just be a good Seeker, but a Viktor Krum-level Golden Snitch snatcher. (Editorâ€™s note: thatâ€™s a stretch. But Mike Evans would definitely give Maximus Brankovitch III a run for his money.) We hear about his experience on a private jet, food picks in Paris and his pregame playlist. Mike is one of the best in the game right now and this episode is one you canâ€™t miss. Listen up. Big Truss. BIG.Â

item.title: A Letter to My Children
item.author: Marvin Jones Jr.
item.description: Marvin Jones Jr. shares his family's personal story and how love has powered the next chapter of their lives.
item.keywords: Danny Amendola,NFL,Detroit Lions,marvin jones,marvin jones jr,detroit,lions,nfl,national football league,sports,college football,los angeles, CA,family,community,support,football
item.content:encoded:
Dear Marv, Mareon, Murrell and Mya,

I have something to tell you. Something I want to talk about.Â

Itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve mostly kept to myself up to now, and you might not fully understand it right at this moment, but I need for you to hear it.

Itâ€™s tough to talk about even all these months later, but after your little brother Marlo passed away in Decemberâ€¦.

Daddy was ready to call it quits.

Not just football, either. Iâ€™m talking just get away from â€¦ everything.

Leave the country. Move to Spain. Hunker down. Just us and Mommy. That sort of thing. Never talk to anyone ever again, never have to face anyone or discuss anything, just shield us all from the entire outside world. You know what I mean?

We were all just struggling so much.

Mom and me was one thing, but hearing Mya ask, â€œWhen is Marlo coming back down from heaven?â€ Seeing that teddy bear that you guys called by his name? It was beyond heartbreaking.

We always told you guys it was O.K. to cry and to let your feelings out.

But sometimes thatâ€™s not so easy. Even for Dad.

Me and Mommy tried our best to stay strong in front of you guys, and to make sure you understood that we were going to get through this no matter what. We knew youâ€™d be watching us â€” looking to us for how we were handling such an unimaginable tragedy. So we did our best. But the reality is.â€¦

I was really hurting.

Early on Iâ€™d try to act â€œnormalâ€ all day and not show any hurt, and then Iâ€™d just lie down in bed at night and itâ€™d all come out at once. So, yeah, those first few days, it all just felt like too much.

But thatâ€™s not what I wanted to tell you.

I mention all that stuff because I need you to understand the backdrop for what I do want to talk about. And that isâ€¦.

What happened next.

A few days after our little angel left us, as sad as we all were â€¦ something truly amazing happened. Something inspiring.

And thatâ€™s actually what I want to tell you about.

All of sudden, folks just kept showing up at our front door. And, at first, I gotta be honest ... I didnâ€™t want to answer. But the doorbell just kept ringing.

Matthew and Kelly Stafford.

Danny Amendola.

Kenny Golladay.

Coach Patricia. Coach Prince. Other members of the organization.Â

All showing us love. Giving us support. Letting us know that they were there for us.

I mean, you guys ... it was so moving what they did for our family.

Iâ€™m getting choked up right now just sitting here writing about it. But back then? In that moment? Iâ€™m not lying when I say that their visits, that supportâ€¦.

It changed something inside of me.

I went from wanting to be closed off and isolated from pretty much everyone to realizing beyond a shadow of a doubt that our family needed all the love and support we could get.

So after those first few visits, our door was wide open. You guys remember it. Everyone in the family flew up to Michigan. Your grandparents, aunts and uncles on both sides. Auntie Leslie even flew in from China.

Everyone rallied around us.

And as tough as those first few days were, I always want you guys to remember how our family and friends came together to lift us up and help us all get through the most difficult experience of our lives.

Local businesses and restaurants sent over food and care packages. Police and firefighters stopped by to lend their support. Friends, sports fans, and just regular folks from all around the world sent us their well-wishes and shared their stories of loss with us to make sure we knew we werenâ€™t alone.Â

It was powerful. And it goes to show something I want you guys to always rememberâ€¦.Â

It really does take a community sometimes. Sometimes you canâ€™t do things on your own.

People need people.

It really does take a community sometimes. Sometimes you canâ€™t do things on your own. People need people.

The other big point to remember â€” and this is maybe the most important thing of all in terms of your lives going forward â€” is that the good people in this world outnumber the bad by a wide margin. Those who are kindhearted and eager to lend a hand â€¦ those folks are everywhere.

Please never doubt that for a second.Â

I know itâ€™s sometimes easy to get down about the negativity and hatred and pessimism that we see online or on the news, but those people, that mindset? When push comes to shove â€¦ it has no chance against the good people of the world.

When something like what happened to us takes place, you learn that real quick.

But the important thing is that you never forget it.

That you never stop letting it inspire you to show that same love and compassion throughout your own lives. I can tell you for certain that the kindness and support that our family received made a lasting impact on Mommy and me.

Your mom is in the process of starting up a foundation that will help other families who have gone through what we all experienced over the past year â€” a place for sharing stories, and where families can lend support to one another.

And the outpouring of support we experienced over this past year definitely inspired us to want to do even more once the pandemic hit. Daddy looked at himself in the mirror and asked, Am I doing enough to help right now? Mommy did the same. And we both agreed that we needed to do all that we could to support first responders and everyone else putting their own health and well-being on the line for the rest of us. We wanted to do our part to let those folks know that they were not alone, and that we all had their backs, and to help them feel the same power of community that had lifted us up over the past year.

Iâ€™m so proud that you guys were with us for every step of that journey, and the joy and happiness that you each experienced from helping others is something that will be in my heart forever.

It was inspiring for me.

At the same time, while the struggles and suffering of the coronavirus pandemic were going down, we all couldnâ€™t help but look for silver linings wherever we could find them. And as heartbreaking as the pandemic has been on so many levels, I have to say that I am grateful that it has allowed our family to be together for an extended period of time â€” and at a moment when I truly believe that we needed that more than ever.

After your brotherâ€™s passing, we absolutely needed to be together like that, we really, really did. And for your mom and me, being able to spend so much time with you guys was a blessing.

Believe me when I tell you, every moment together this year has been cherished.

To the fullest.

Often people tend to think that the parents do everything for their kids, and teach all the lessons and set the standard, but in so many ways, it was actually your resilience and strength and positivity that helped us get through this year.Â

And at the end of the day we all made it through together.

I donâ€™t want to go on too long â€” I know for a fact that a few of you have Zoom homework assignments to get to! â€” but before I get out of here, there are just two last things I want to make sure you understand.

First, please know that during the past year you guys have brought an immense amount of joy into Mommy and Daddyâ€™s lives. Even in the hardest of times, you allowed us to see and experience what real, pure love looks like.

Sometimes us grown-ups make life so complicated, and get caught up in our jobs, or all the other things that we need to take care of from day to day. But you guys, you brought Mom and me back to our childhoods this year. Just watching you run around and jump and laugh, and then doing all those things right alongside you guys â€¦ it really was the best.

Everything became so simple and genuine and pure. You guys made it all about love, and appreciating our time together, and that really put everything in perspective for us. I canâ€™t tell you how much that meant to me and Mommy.

It was like we were both 12 again â€” playing kickball in the house, trying to remember the rules of handball, having epic Barbie doll playdates, doing double Dutch (DOUBLE DUTCH!!!) together. All of a sudden, we were back in the â€™90s.

And you guys had us laughing and smiling again.

Heck, Marv even taught me how to make TikToks!

At one point I remember pulling your mom aside and whispering, â€œAre these our kids or our siblings?â€

Because we were all having so much fun together.

You guys, you brought Mom and me back to our childhoods this year.

Of course, weâ€™ll never ever forget Marlo. Weâ€™ll always remember the wonderful times we had together with him. And I know heâ€™s been smiling down on us from heaven while weâ€™ve been doing all that stuff together. I know heâ€™s proud of you guys, and he surely knows how much of a difference you made in helping your parents cope this year.

So on behalf of both Mom and I, and your baby brother Marlo, I just want to sayâ€¦.

Thank you.

And last, but certainly not least, I just want to say that Mommy and me are so excited for you guys to meet the newest member of our family.

After Marlo was born, your mom and I had decided that there werenâ€™t going to be any additional brothers or sisters joining our family. But after his passing ... you guys let it be known that you had other ideas.Â Â

And, I mean â€¦ how could we ignore that?

It was probably the fastest and easiest change of plans in the history of the world.

And now, when your baby sister arrives in February, you guys can know that she is here because of Marlo, and because of what he meant to you guys. What he still means to all of us.

Your baby sister will be another of about a million reminders of how special Marlo was.

And, you know what elseâ€¦? She is going to be joining one heck of a family!

With all my love,

Daddy

item.title: Letter to My Younger Self
item.author: Mike Modano
item.description: Itâ€™s not going to take two days or two weeks for it to hit you that you won the Stanley Cup â€” itâ€™s going to hit you right then and there.
item.content:encoded:
Dear 29-year-old Mike,

I got to let you know something before you go out there for triple overtime in Buffalo.

I know, I know, youâ€™ve got to be out on the ice with your guys. But youâ€™re going to want to hear this. Because youâ€™re about to go through one of the most amazing, important times in your life. And when it ends, those memories are going to last forever.

So know this: That feeling you have, deep down, thatâ€™s telling you itâ€™s going to be really, really tough to bounce back if this thing goes seven? That feeling is the truth. Youâ€™ve got a broken wrist that youâ€™re numbing every day and praying that it doesnâ€™t get worse each shift. Hullâ€™s on a bad knee and heâ€™s probably not suiting up for Game 7. The boys in the room are out of gas. This is it. This is really it.

You could have never dreamed of whatâ€™s on the other side of this period.

I mean, do you remember clearing off the snow on the lake that you used to live on outside of Detroit?

Do you remember how this all began?

Dad taught you how to skate out there when you were six years old and, man, once you got started there was no going back. You knew right away that you just loved to skate. Then you moved off the lake, so Mom built you a little rink in the backyard in the winters and you were out there basically every waking hour. And the funny thing is, you didnâ€™t even know a lick about the sport, really.

When you were five, and Dad was working his construction job, he had a talk with a few of the boys he hired to help him. They were the Rankin brothers. Jack, Mike and Bobby Rankin. Jack played some semipro hockey in his day and Bobby played in college up at St. Lawrence.

Dad told them that you had too much energy. Like way too much energy. You were always getting up to no good around the house and bothering Mom. At Kindergarten class, the teachers would complain that youâ€™d never pay attention like the other kids did and you always had to be doing something.

So Dad and the Rankin boys had an idea to keep you moving.

Hockey.

They thought that if they strapped some skates on you, you could make something of all that energy.

You understood, right away, what they were thinking. Once you got outside, and you skated in the open air on the lake â€¦ you were hooked. That feeling of the cold wind hitting your face harder and harder the faster you go drew you back out there every day.

As you got older, you started to discover that the sport exists outside of your backyard. You and Dad would watch channel nine on Saturday nights to see those great Toronto and Montreal teams play. Sittler, Salming for the Leafs. Lafleur, Robinson for the Habs. These guys lit up on the TV. And since Dad was from Boston, on family vacations up there during the holidays, youâ€™d go to the Garden with him and see the Bruins play. The electricity in the building stayed with you long after you left.

Back home, it was just a 30-minute drive to the Joe in Detroit, where the Wings played. They were going through a tough stretch back when you were a boy. But the fans in town always had a great passion for their team. Hockey, in that part of our country, meant a lot to everyone. And the Wings gave back to their community in a bunch of different ways. You were part of that when you started going to Little Caesars hockey camps when you were 10. That took the game to a whole new level for you.

Through those camps, you were able to see more games at the Joe and fall in love with the sport even more. You began to compete against some of the best players in the area, and that led to a tough decision.

One thing a lot of people donâ€™t know is that you thought about trying to make it in tennis. You were a pretty good player as a boy, and for a bit you considered going to Florida to try and really give it a run in tennis.

Mike Modano, the tennis pro. Maybe in another life.

But in this life, you chased that feeling of freedom that only hockey could give you. That led to you, Mom and Dad making another big choice. Going to Canada for juniors was the best option if you were going to try and make it to the NHL. But it was a big choice. Mom was a bit hesitant to send you up there, especially because you were only 16.

Rick Wilson, the head coach of the Prince Albert Raiders in Saskatchewan called you up in the summer of â€™86, telling you how he wanted you to come up there and what he believed was possible for you. There was no changing your mind after that.

But in this life, you chased that feeling of freedom that only hockey could give you.

Do you remember how confident you were in the decision?

Mom and Dad â€” though they wanted a few more years of you at home â€” knew it was the right call, too.

In Prince Albert, youâ€™d meet two of the most important people youâ€™d ever come across.

Ralph and Carol Ring, your billet family.

One of their sons, Martin, had just moved out, but Stephen was still there. They made your transition from Livonia to your new home as easy as you could have ever imagined. Ralph worked as an executive with the Raiders and Carol worked in city hall, but she would sing the anthem before games. They, like everyone in the town, had a deep connection to the team. The Raiders were the heartbeat of Prince Albert.

Coach Wilson and his wife, who was also named Carol, were such great leaders for that team.

You know, itâ€™s funny, because when people think of you down the road, a lot of them are going to remember you for your skating. That will be a point of pride for you. But what they wonâ€™t know is that you were a bit of late bloomer when it came to really finding that explosive stride. It wasnâ€™t until Carol Wilson, who was a great figure skater, worked with you that you started to find that next level. She made your stride a bit longer and all of sudden you gained a step on some of the older kids playing in the WHL.

Thatâ€™s what people in Prince Albert do, they help one another.

It was a small farm town, but they loved their hockey. I mean, of course, the whole country of Canada did. The word passionate doesnâ€™t quite cover it. So when you got to town, there was definitely some push-back about an American being up there and scoring as many points as you did. I know you remember that part. Some of the other teams always had a few guys in their bottom six that wanted to take a run at you or remind you that you werenâ€™t at home anymore.

But you got through it. I know how much you loved Prince Albert once you got to know it. You spent summers up there and youâ€™ll keep in touch with those friends you made outside the rink for life.

In the summer of â€™87, you began to see what could happen when your time with the Raiders was done.

That year, the draft was at the Joe in Detroit. Even though you werenâ€™t eligible until the next year, you and Dad went to see what it was all about. A few of the guys you played against in the WHL got picked in the first round, including Joe Sakic. You lined up against him a couple of times the year before. He was a great player and you knew if you worked hard in your draft year, you could have a chance to go early in the first round, too.

That next season, you didnâ€™t hear much about the draft until after the world juniors ended in Moscow in January. You guys didnâ€™t have a great tournament, but when you got back home the NHL released the Central Scouting Bureau draft rankings, and you saw your name up at the top with Trevor Linden.

Hereâ€™s the thing about the draft, that you might not fully appreciate for some time: Going first overall will mean a lot to you â€” to American hockey â€” as you get older. I know, at the time, you just wanted to be an NHL player. But receiving the honor of being the second American to be selected first â€¦ thatâ€™s a big deal. Trevor was a great junior player, so to battle with him through the end of that â€™88 season will help you grow.

The draft was at the forum in Montreal. Your whole family was there with you, including Ralph and Carol.

I know you knew that it was likely youâ€™d go first or second, to Minnesota or Vancouver. But I also know you looked up and down that draft board and let your mind wander. You saw Pittsburgh had the fourth pick and you wondered, A career playing beside Mario â€¦ what would that be like?

But when Lou Nanne made the call to take you first overall, youâ€™d learn that Minnesota was the place you wanted to be. That passion Michiganders have for hockey is matched by Minnesotans. And you were lucky to join a franchise like the North Stars.

The TSN interview after the pick, where you were sweaty and more nervous than youâ€™d ever been, wasnâ€™t your best. But at least your braces were off. Did you forget how you got them off a few weeks before? New teeth, new job. Pretty good week, I think.

After another year in Prince Albert, you finally had to say goodbye to the Rings and the Raiders. You headed to Kalamazoo for training camp with the North Stars in the summer of â€™89 and you learned, real quick, that the NHL was a big step up from the WHL. You walked into the locker room and saw guys like Brian Bellows, Stew Gavins and Basil McRae. You werenâ€™t in Saskatchewan anymore.

You also realized in your first practice that you werenâ€™t the fastest anymore.

That shook you a bit. But everyone in the room did a good job of welcoming you and making you feel a part of the team. That made your rookie season a bit easier.

But, Mike, Iâ€™ve got a quick piece of advice for you here.

Donâ€™t get in another fight. Just donâ€™t do it. I know, I know, when you dropped the gloves with Rod Brindâ€™Amour that year, it made sense in the moment. But, yeah, he handled you pretty good. You did your best â€¦ but just donâ€™t look up the fight on the Internet when youâ€™re older either. That part of the game just isnâ€™t for you, pal.

In Minnesota, you grew into the player you always wanted to be. The Stanley Cup run in â€™91 taught you a lot about what it takes to win in this league. You guys snuck into the playoffs that year with 68 points, but you learned quickly that it doesnâ€™t matter how you got there â€” what matters is that youâ€™re there.

The fans in Minnesota packed the arena every night during those playoffs and you only lost one home game before the Cup final. That Pittsburgh team that you ran into, man, they were good, right? Mario, Jagr, Coffeyâ€¦. They could really play. They beat you guys in six, and it stung for a while.

I know you remember that feeling this year before you played Buffalo.Â

But, of course, thereâ€™s a big difference with this yearâ€™s team. You arenâ€™t playing for Minnesota anymore. The team moved to Dallas in 1993 and I know it wasnâ€™t easy on you to say goodbye to the people of Minnesota. You were one of the leaders on that team and those last few games at the Met Center were pretty emotional. I know seeing those little boys and girls in their North Stars gear â€” knowing they wonâ€™t have a team the next year â€” that hurt.

But hockey is a business sometimes, you know that.

Not many of the guys could really believe that theyâ€™d be heading to Texas, though.

Remember when they broke the news to the team.

Dallas? Really? Thatâ€™s Cowboy country.

They had won back-to-back Super Bowls the year you headed out there and it was pretty obvious that, no matter what you did, or what they did, they were going to be the front-page story. In a way it took some of the pressure off of you as players. You were able to do your thing and try to help build up a fan base however the team wanted because people were pretty new to the sport. America wasnâ€™t the hockey hotbed it is now. In â€™93 it had only been a couple years since the Gretzky trade so the southern half of the country was still coming around on the game.

But, you noticed right away how nearly every fan who made it to a game in those first few years left with a smile on their face. And they always wanted to come back for another one. Even though the team struggled a bit those first few years, you were all building something special down there.

Those Dallas fans are smart when it comes to their sports though, you saw that. After a couple of years of being there they wanted a winner. In â€™96, when things werenâ€™t going so well, Ken Hitchcock came in to coach the team and things began to change, almost immediately. He pushed you hard. There were times when guys in the room would look at each other like, Can this guy just relax for a day?

But that was Hitch.

That summer after he came in, you sat with him and Bob Gainey, the GM, and you worked out how you could help this team get over the hill and bring a Cup to Dallas. You all decided that it would be best to add some more dimensions to your game, to make you a 200-foot player and those types of responsibilities would be given to all the veterans on the team.

You know, when you look back on how the â€™99 Cup run came to be, youâ€™ll remember the preseason trips to Vail. When Hitch took over, he made those trips to Colorado mandatory before the season started and it really helped all the guys get to know each other. There was a lot of bonding, training and a bit of golf, too. That trip in â€™99, everyone knew before the season started that the team had to make a deep run that year. The fans in Dallas were hungry and they knew you and the team were capable of getting it done.

You saw how the team shaped up that year. You knew going into the playoffs that this was going to be special. From the veterans in the room like Brett Hull and Guy Carbonneau, to leaders like Derian Hatcher and Joe Nieuwendyk and all the way through the lineup to Ed Belfour in net â€” this group was built to win big games. You just had to prove it.

When you look back on how the â€™99 Cup run came to be, youâ€™ll remember the preseason trips to Vail.

In the Conference Finals you played that great Avalanche team with the guy you saw in â€™87 at the draft, Joe Sakic. They were an excellent group and after they beat you at home in Game 5, you were down 3â€“2. Those next two games, and you know this, they were some of the best hockey youâ€™ve ever been a part of. From top to bottom Hitch had you guys executing in every zone, on every shift. To go back to Colorado and win there, then to survive a Game 7â€¦. Iâ€™m sure it felt like destiny that you would beat Buffalo in the finals.

But now youâ€™re here. In the locker room of the Marine Midland Arena in Buffalo, and itâ€™s getting late.

Itâ€™s Game 6. Youâ€™re up 3â€“2 in the series. And youâ€™re about to head out there for triple overtime.

Look around. You see how beat the guys are?

Look at Hitch. He even looks tired.

But, man, this is it.

When you get out there, just try to get the puck in their zone. Thatâ€™s the first step. Theyâ€™ve got an incredible goalie in Hasek. Heâ€™s on tonight. Youâ€™ve got to get some traffic in front of him and make him work. As the period goes on, just try to cycle it and make them skate as much as possible.

Late in the frame, when the body is hurting the most, thatâ€™s when youâ€™ll get your chance.

Youâ€™ll get the puck in the corner, youâ€™ll shake free of Zhitnik and try to play along the wall. The puck will sort of fumble toward the net, so stay with it. Hully will be out there with you and itâ€™ll be one of his first shifts in a while because of his knee. Heâ€™ll be near the crease and then itâ€™s just going to happen.

Itâ€™ll be a blur. No matter how much detail I describe it to you in, itâ€™s going to be a blur.

Youâ€™ll be trying to get the puck and next thing you know, Hasek will be on his stomach and Hully will be screaming.

Itâ€™s not going to take two days or two weeks for it to hit you that you won the Stanley Cup â€” itâ€™s going to hit you right then and there. Itâ€™s the best feeling in the world, Mike. It really is. Youâ€™re going to cry for two hours straight that night, I promise.

The pain in your wrist, in your legs â€” itâ€™ll all just fade away in a split second as you wheel into the corner with Hully.

Youâ€™ll skate around the ice with the Cup over your head, and itâ€™ll feel like it weighs a pound, not 35.

When you get back to the locker room, before the press and the friends and family can come in, there will be a moment.

Everyone on the team, from the coaches to the players, will have a chance to huddle in the middle of the room and tell each other what this experience â€” what this night â€” means to them. I want you to look around at all those guys and really soak it all. Remember your own journey. From the lake in Livonia, to Saskatchewan, to Minnesota and all the way to Dallas. Think about all the people who made this possible. Know each guy in that room has a story like yours.

Appreciate those guys and what youâ€™ve all just accomplished.

Youâ€™re going to cry for two hours straight that night, I promise.

When you get back home to Dallas, and you see Young Street packed with thousands and thousands of Stars fans, itâ€™s going to blow your mind. There will be hundreds at DFW to welcome you back when you land, too. Itâ€™s going to be incredible, trust me.

But what will take some time to set in is that your team changed the sport of hockey in the state of Texas â€” forever. Youâ€™ll notice in the few years after the Cup that the atmosphere at your home games is truly the best in the league. The fans will stand all game during the playoffs and every shot, hit and goal will sound like a touchdown at Cowboy Stadium. Dallas will become a hockey destination, because of what that â€™99 team did.

That to me, Mike, is legacy.

Be proud of that.

The Stanley Cup isnâ€™t everything. But I wanted you to really appreciate the journey you went on with those guys, and know that that team still matters to the people of Texas.

Thereâ€™s plenty more for you in the game after â€™99.

But, to be honest here, I donâ€™t want to spoil it all for you.

Thereâ€™s great things coming. From playing for the Wings, to retirement, to seeing your jersey go to the rafters in Prince Albert, to the Hockey Hall of Fame â€” this game will give you more than you could have imagined.Â You'll meet Allison, the love of your life. She will be your best friend and with her you'll find the most fulfilling life after hockey.Â But most importantly, youâ€™ll become a father to Kate, Jack, Reese, Luca and Quinn.Â Your family will be the greatest blessing of all. And thatâ€™ll change the way you see the world forever. I canâ€™t wait for you to experience that.

There will come a time in your life when youâ€™re not playing hockey anymore. Youâ€™ll go to events, or meet people, and somebody will introduce you as â€œMike Modano, one of the greatest American hockey players of all time.â€

I know you didnâ€™t grow up thinking about becoming that. All you wanted was to be a good teammate and win a Stanley Cup. But I hope that when that day comes, and you see the impact you had on the game, that it means something to you. Your generation of American players â€” guys like Hully, Tkachuk, Guerin, Roenick and so many others â€” helped pave the way for the game to reach another level here in the U.S. Those world-class players youâ€™ll see on TV when you get older, know that some of them look up to you guys right now.

You and your family worked hard to reach this point, know that. Youâ€™re one of the lucky ones who gets to play this game for a living.

So when you head out there for triple overtime, remember to cherish every second of it.

And make sure Hully gets the puck.

item.title: Always Prepared
item.author: Josh Hart
item.description: Whether he was 6th man or starter, Josh Hart was always ready for the moment. Ahead of the 2020 NCAA season, former @NovaMBB guard discusses the values he learn
item.content:encoded: Whether he was sixth man or starter, Josh Hart was always ready for the moment. Ahead of the 2020 NCAA season, the former Villanova guard discusses the values he learned from Coach Jay Wright.

item.title: The Next Generation
item.author: Obi Toppin
item.description: The thing about streetball is that thereâ€™s no hiding. I grew up in New York City, and my earliest childhood memories involve places like Dyckman court in Inwood
item.content:encoded:
The thing about streetball is that thereâ€™s no hiding.

I grew up in New York City, and my earliest childhood memories involve places like Dyckman court in Inwood, West 4th Street and, of course, Rucker Park.Â

When youâ€™re on those courts, thereâ€™s no faking it. You either ball or youâ€™re gonna hear about it.Â

And when I say â€œhear about it,â€ I donâ€™t mean a coach pulling you aside. I mean the announcer on the mic, the other team, everybody in the bleachers, and the people hanging out of windows â€” or 30 floors up on a roof â€” letting you hear about it.Â

When you have that level of pressure and the atmosphere it creates â€” thereâ€™s just nothing like it.

I grew up getting to watch some of the greatest playground legends ever, but my favorite player of all time goes by â€œDunkerâ€™s Delight.â€Â

Let me tell you about Dunkerâ€™s Delight.

It doesnâ€™t take a lot of imagination to figure out how he got his nickname. My man could throw it down from anywhere. Cradle-reverse dunk? Easy. 360 windmill? Might as well be a layup. He could fly.Â

He was on the Court Kingz, a streetball team that traveled around the country, kind of like the Harlem Globetrotters. He got his nickname for his dunking, of course, but what made him truly stand out was that there was so much more to his game. He could shoot from anywhere, make no-look passes, had unreal handle, and could get to the basket whenever he wanted. But make no mistake, if you thought of yourself as a rim protector, Dunkerâ€™s Delight was ready to put you on a poster.Â

There were so many young ballers who were inspired by his game, who dreamed of being able to play like him. Dreaming of one day maybe having that level of respect and legend status that he had every time he rolled up to a court.

Dunkerâ€™s Delight is my hero â€¦ and he also happens to be my dad, Obadiah Toppin.

Thatâ€™s actually how I ended up getting a nickname of my own: â€œthe Next Generation.â€Â

Dunkerâ€™s Delight is my hero â€¦ and he also happens to be my dad, Obadiah Toppin.

Thatâ€™s what they called me when my dad started letting me play in games with him when I was 12. Oh my God, you want to talk about nerves. I was just a scrawny kid out there, and because of my dad I was running with the most amazing players as theyâ€™re putting on a show. You know, just the other day, I was watching a YouTube highlight of me throwing him an off-the-backboard alley-oop. I still pull those videos up every now and then just to kind of take me back to those times.Â

Back then, the idea of playing in the NBA â€” or even in college â€” seemed far off. I wasnâ€™t any kind of standout. As far as I knew, those games I played with the Court Kingz might have been my basketball peak. And honestly? That would have been O.K., because sharing the court with my dad is always going to be one of the coolest things Iâ€™ve ever done. My dad didnâ€™t have to give me those experiences â€” it wasnâ€™t like there were a lot of kids running around when the Court Kingz played â€” but he did.Â

Over the years my family really struggled while my dad attempted to live out his basketball dream. I canâ€™t tell you how many times I moved growing up. Seriously, I canâ€™t even begin to count. There was nobody who believed in my dadâ€™s abilities more than I did, and seeing him struggle made me realize just what a grind it truly was to make a living playing this game.Â

We struggled a lot. We moved around to a lot of different apartments, and most of them werenâ€™t places I want to remember. Itâ€™s easy to lose focus and fall down the wrong path in that situation. And thatâ€™s why I was lucky that my dad wasnâ€™t the only hero in my family. My mom? Sheâ€™s a real legend, too. Not necessarily for her game â€” although she did coach a little bit â€” but because she was the one who gave my family stability growing up. No matter where we were, she always held us together.Â

When it came to my own basketball dreams, I knew I just needed to be good enough for someone to give me a scholarship to play basketball in order to take the financial burden off my parents.Â

But just getting to play after high school actually seemed like kind of a long shot. Usually top prospects follow a schedule where theyâ€™re basically on track for big things by the time theyâ€™re sophomores. But I was a late bloomer. Didnâ€™t dunk for the first time until the beginning of my senior year â€” and that one barely grazed the rim. (Still counts!) And by the time I finished high school, basketball still hadnâ€™t really clicked for me. I wasnâ€™t at the level I knew I had to be at to play in college. But I still believed that I could get there. Maybe not the NBA, but I could get that scholarship and maybe even play overseas, like my dad had.Â

Ultimately, I decided to go to prep school â€” to take one year to prove myself â€” and that was when my mindset changed. I began to have higher expectations and ambitions for myself, and I stopped letting other distractions get in the way. For the first time in my life, I truly focused all of my energy on my game. Just like at Dyckman or Rucker, I knew being average wasnâ€™t an option.Â

During that year, I learned a lot about myself, my game matured, and my dunks werenâ€™t just grazing over the rim anymore. Now I could do all the same dunks as my dad (and a few new ones of my own). And for the first time I started getting some recognition for more than being the son of a famous streetball player. College programs actually began to show real interest in me.Â

The opportunity to play college ball and really try to take basketball as far as I could was about more than me. I was living out this dream for my dad, too. Heâ€™d made a name for himself, and I was the next generation. That honor has never been lost on me.

I visited a few different college programs, and they all had certain things I liked. But then I went to this place Iâ€™d never been before in Ohio. It was called Dayton.Â

And I never wanted to leave.

Itâ€™s not an exaggeration to say that I was home the moment I set foot in Dayton.

As soon as I landed at the airport, I had random people somehow recognizing who I was and telling me to come play there. And it wasnâ€™t just at the airport â€” when we walked around campus, everyone seemed to be in on it. Everyone we passed had huge smiles, and theyâ€™d be chatting up my mom about what a great school it was and how tight-knit the community was.Â

You have to understand, having moved around to so many places growing up, I wasnâ€™t accustomed to really walking around somewhere and having people say hi and ask how I was doing. And like, really mean it.Â

Everywhere you looked, there were flags and signs supporting the team. It was clear that basketball at Dayton was a very, very big deal.Â

Coach Grant knew that I wanted to play at the next level, and the only thing he promised me on that very first recruiting visit was that heâ€™d do everything he could to prepare me. And he also told me that if I ever was ready to make that jump, heâ€™d let me know. He didnâ€™t promise me the moon, but he also didnâ€™t tell me it would be impossible to get there. It was on me.Â

The outside world might see Dayton and think of it as just a mid-major program that makes some noise from time to time â€” but they donâ€™t really get it. Dayton is a town that lives basketball. Itâ€™s the thing that really brings everyone together, and only when youâ€™re part of that do you feel how important it is.Â

Everybody in Dayton loves the basketball team â€” and I just happened to play for it. It really wasnâ€™t hard to put your whole heart into the game because everyone else did, too â€” the players, the coaches and definitely the fans. That was just the culture. Not surprisingly, the more time I spent there, the more I started growing as a person and a player.Â

At the end of my second year on campus, I met with Coach Grant. Iâ€™d been named to the All-Conference team and gotten a few other awards, too. He told me that I wasnâ€™t ready for the NBA, but that I should test out the draft process to get a feel for it, and so I could get feedback from teams. Then he said something else, something that I still remember vividly, â€œAfter that, come back here, put on a show and leave a legacy.â€

As my fatherâ€™s son, the word legacy means a lot to me. I had a belief that the NBA would be there for me later, but I knew that I still had another dream to chase.Â

Everybody else in the college basketball world might have been sleeping on us, but Coach knew we were building something. It wasnâ€™t just because of me â€” we had Jalen Crutcher, and seniors like Trey Landers and Ryan Mikesell, just so many guys who could ball. We knew we had a team that could play with anybody. We just needed to prove it.Â

Our opportunity came in Maui.Â

The Maui Invitational usually attracts some of the biggest programs in college basketball. It wasnâ€™t even that we werenâ€™t the favorites there â€” we werenâ€™t even a team most people looked twice at. We were basically expected to just be a warmup for the bigger schools.

But that expectation changed pretty quickly after our first game.Â

We played Georgia, which was led by Anthony Edwards, a name familiar to anybody keeping up with the NBA draft. We went into that game with zero expectations from anybody, and we didnâ€™t just win, we dominated. Then we did the same thing to Virginia Tech, and at that point right there, we knew, O.K., this is the team we are.

That championship game against Kansas, well â€¦ I still think about it a lot. What I never appreciated when I was watching those Maui games on ESPN growing up, is just how tiny the arena in Lahaina is. Youâ€™re basically in a high school gymnasium, playing these super high-stakes games. And against Kansas â€” I donâ€™t know how they got so many fans in there, but it was loud. I still remember Jalen trying to say something to me during the game and just seeing his mouth move but not hearing any noise come out.Â

We ultimately took them to overtime before losing. It was a great game, but we knew that if we saw them again, it was going to be different. We wouldnâ€™t drop the next one.

The season after that point, man, itâ€™s like a blur to be honest â€” just like ... too many good times.Â

Look, we won 20 games in a row heading into March. If Iâ€™m lucky Iâ€™ll get to experience a lot of great things during my basketball career. But I know for certain, that 20-game run with my best friends is something Iâ€™m always going to treasure. It was difficult to really describe what the excitement and hype around Dayton was. The town had gone through multiple tragedies leading up to the season, so for us to serve as this positive thing to be excited about â€” and all the energy the fans there gave us â€” it was amazing.Â

By the time we made it to the Atlantic 10 tournament, our ambitions were huge. We wanted to win it. We wanted a No. 1 seed. And we wanted another shot at Kansas.Â

I was really excited about the conference tournament because it was played in Brooklyn, so it felt like a kind of homecoming. Leading up to it, weâ€™d heard some rumors about games maybe being postponed because of a virus or something, but my focus was on what we had to prove there.Â

I remember the night we arrived, the plan was to watch the end of the Fordham-Duquesne game and then go to bed because we had an early workout at the Netsâ€™ facility.Â

As halftime was ending, I noticed the teams werenâ€™t coming out of their locker rooms to warm up for the second half. At first I thought, Oh, thatâ€™s weird. Where are they? Then it clicked in my head what was actually going on. It was at that moment that my stomach just dropped.Â

I knew it was over.Â

The season was going to get canceled.Â

Not long after that, Coach called us in for a meeting and made it official â€” there wouldnâ€™t be a conference tournament or an NCAA tournament. It was over.Â

And like that we were on a bus back to Dayton. The 20 wins, the No. 3 ranking, the legacy we were building â€” they were all gone.Â

There were a lot of tears on that bus ride. It just didnâ€™t feel real. Like, How could this be how the story ends?Â

We were hurting not just for us, but also for the community. We knew how much our team meant to it, how weâ€™d become this source of hope. Our fans deserved to enjoy watching us play, and to get their moment in the national spotlight.Â

And I just felt terrible for my teammates. Iâ€™d built up a name for myself throughout the season, but the tournament was when I knew Jalen, Trey and Ryan would get their chance to show what they could do. And on that huge stage, the world would finally see what I saw in every game and every practice â€” that we had a team good enough to beat anybody. A team that expected to beat anybody.Â

My heart still hurts over us not getting that chance to truly prove ourselves. But with time, Iâ€™ve gotten a little more perspective.Â

If youâ€™d told me three years ago â€” when I was trying to figure out some way to keep playing basketball â€” that one day Iâ€™d be on a D-I team that won 20 games in a row? I probably wouldnâ€™t have believed you. If you told me that six years ago, I for sure wouldnâ€™t have believed you.Â

And while I didnâ€™t get to end my career at Dayton the way I wanted to, that doesnâ€™t take away from what we did accomplish. I donâ€™t think anybody who was part of what we did will ever forget it.Â

Not long after we got back to campus, Coach Grant pulled me into his office. Weâ€™d had a lot of meetings over the years, but this one was really short. He just looked me in the eyes and said, â€œItâ€™s time to leave. Youâ€™re ready.â€Â

I didnâ€™t get to experience a lot of things that I hoped I would last year, but that one moment of validation is one that I know will always stay with me.Â

My heart still hurts over us not getting that chance to truly prove ourselves.

We all have dreams, ones maybe we just keep in the back of our minds but never really express. You work toward it and work toward it for a long time, usually never knowing if youâ€™ll ever get anywhere. Most of my life, I didnâ€™t know if Iâ€™d ever be ready for the NBA. Such a small fraction of people are. Me and my family appreciate as much as anybody how hard it is to pursue this life, the sacrifices it takes.

Being pulled aside for a â€œYouâ€™re readyâ€ from someone like Coach Grant â€” someone I just respect so much â€” and knowing he meant it, I just started crying. No, it wasnâ€™t how I thought my career at Dayton would end. I never got to cut down those nets with my teammates, or run around the court celebrating on national TV.Â

Itâ€™s easy to get swept up in the things you canâ€™t control â€” particularly in the time weâ€™re living in now. But this whole experience has taught me just how important it is to maximize what I can control â€” to put my focus on building up myself and my relationships so that Iâ€™m ready for whatever happens.Â

Like right now, did I expect to be thinking about the NBA draft in November? With everything done remotely? Uh, no. That wasnâ€™t how I quite dreamed it up.

But that doesnâ€™t take away from the big picture. To be on the brink of being drafted into the NBA, having the chance to represent my dad, and feel like I truly earned that name the Next Generation? Well, that means everything. Thatâ€™s what matters.

I didnâ€™t get to this moment the way I imagined, but at the same time, Iâ€™ve never really taken the traditional path to anywhere. Iâ€™ve just always been really lucky to have the right people in my life to guide me along.

I still get asked all the time: How do you think you guys would have done in the NCAA tournament?Â

And speaking as a soon-to-be-professional who handles things very professionally, I donâ€™t like dwelling on the past and talking in hypotheticals.Â

O.K., thatâ€™s out of the way.

Now, in my heart, as a Flyer, do I truly believe we would have been the last team standing at the end of March Madness?

Hell yeah.Â

No doubt.

item.title: Sharpen the Arrow
item.author: Jamal Murray
item.description: The first martial arts movie I ever watched was this old Chinese film called "Five Deadly Venoms." I was seven years old. I wanted to know more about this forei
item.content:encoded:
The first martial arts movie I ever watched was this old Chinese film calledÂ Five Deadly Venoms.Â I was seven years old. My dad and I were sitting in front of the TV on the floor in our living room.

It starts out with this old kung fu master and his student. Theyâ€™re in a temple or a cave somewhere in China and thereâ€™s smoke rising from a fire. The student is heating water for the masterâ€™s bath. The master is old and dying. He has one last wish. He instructs his student to go on a mission to defeat the masterâ€™s five former pupils, who have turned evil. Each of the bad guys has a unique fighting style named for an animal: the Centipede, the Lizard, the Scorpion, the Snake, and the Toad. To take down each one, the master explains, the student will have to learn all five styles.

As a kid, a lot of these movies went over my head. I couldnâ€™t really follow the dialogue all the time. But that didnâ€™t matter. I just loved them. Even the fact that they were dubbed was cool to me. I wanted to know more about this foreign world, where guys knew how to run up the sides of walls and break down wooden doors with their foreheads. Iâ€™d never seen anything like it. They just had so much â€¦ control.

I grew up in a kung fu house. It wasnâ€™t until I got older that I discovered that most families didnâ€™t talk about the Shaolin Temple or Jackie Chan at the dinner table.

The best part of watching kung fu movies with my dad was the conversations they sparked. We never watched them just for fun.

â€œDo you see how good his balance is?â€ My dad would always zero in on really specific stuff like that. Everything had a potential lesson.

I liked the fighting scenes the best. We would talk about Bruce Lee a lot. I would ask my dad to rewind a Bruce Lee scene so we could watch it again in slo-mo. Bruce would twirl two nunchakus like they were literally an extension of his body.

My dad encouraged me to notice more than just the fighting.

â€œLook at his footwork,â€ he would say. â€œLook at his patience.â€

He would get up really close to the TV, pointing at Bruce Lee on the screen.

â€œWatch how he uses his mind to defeat his enemy.â€

My dad liked to point out that Bruce Lee was small. He was strong, for sure, but he didnâ€™t overpower people with muscle. The mental side of martial arts is what got my dad fired up.

Learning to meditate is one of my earliest memories. I started when I was maybe three or four. I mean, I didnâ€™tÂ knowÂ I was meditating. I just thought it was a weird game my dad had invented. I would sit on the couch and try to remain as still as possible. That wasnâ€™t too hard. Then my dad would try to make me laugh. Heâ€™d make funny faces and think of all kinds of ways to distract me. I was supposed to stay in control and not react â€” to pretend he wasnâ€™t there. But the goal wasnâ€™t to pretend heÂ wasnâ€™tÂ there. It was to clear my mind and notice everything that was going on around me.

As I got older, I got better at it. We would increase the difficulty by meditating in public, on a park bench or in a busy restaurant. Even if I was just quieting my mind for two minutes, I felt like I was building a special muscle that no one could see. Without really knowing it, I was training.

Basketball is my first love. I grew up in Kitchener, Ont., a small town about an hourâ€™s drive from Toronto. Some people know Kitchener as the home of former heavyweight champ Lennox Lewis. And of course, hockey is big there. Itâ€™s Canada. I could never really skate, but I used to offer to play goalie when we played hockey in school. (I was pretty good.) But for me, it was always basketball that called my name. I became known for being the kid who always had a ball in his hands. In grade school I used to take a ball with me to the school and bounce it between my legs the whole way. Then Iâ€™d do it all the way home. I even slept with a ball at times. I remember when I learned to spin a ball on my finger â€” my mom loves this story â€” because I broke several glasses in our kitchen in the process.

My dad would always put a little kung fu into our basketball workouts. â€œPut on this blindfold,â€ my dad would say. Weâ€™d be out on the outdoor court in our backyard.

The court was really just a patch of grass with a hoop. I played out there so much that it became hard dirt. I even made my own three-point line, measuring it out and marking it with sticks. I loved that court.

At first, I really didnâ€™t like the blindfold drill.

â€œWhy are we doing this, Dad?â€ Iâ€™d complain. No one else had to do these drills with their dad, I would tell him.

â€œThis is what it feels like when you arenâ€™t in control,â€ he would respond. â€œYouâ€™re playing blind.â€ It sounded like a kung fu movie. I couldnâ€™t see how this drill was better than just taking a lot of shots.

So Iâ€™d shoot these blind free throws while my dad rebounded. One after another. My dad would get right in my ear, doing his best to get in my head.

â€œMaybe youâ€™re not ready!â€

â€œTime to quit!â€

â€œYouâ€™ve gone fishinâ€™. Youâ€™re done.â€

Sometimes Iâ€™d airball it, but most of the time Iâ€™d hit rim. Not very many went in.

Clank. Clank. Clank.
