Sometimes my dad would hold the ball for a minute at a time, making me wait.

Heâ€™d tell me to take off the blindfold and shoot a few with my eyes open. Then heâ€™d have me put the blindfold back on, and again it would feel weird. I tried to feel all the muscles that went into the mechanics of my shot. The more we did it, the more comfortable it was to not have to rely on my eyes. By high school, we had done the blindfold drill hundreds of times. By that time, when my dad tried to distract me, he was just wasting his time. I could see the hoop in my head.

Swish.Â Swish. Swish.

As I got older, my dadâ€™s ideas about mental discipline seemed less and less weird. I remember driving to my city semifinal game in Grade 10. My dad was driving a sprinter van full of my teammates, and I was in the backseat. Music was blasting and guys were fooling around, making jokes and all of that. Our nerves were bouncing off the walls inside that van.

About halfway there, my dad turned around and gave me a stare.

â€œSettle down and focus.â€

He said it loud enough so only I heard him.

I closed my eyes. The van was bumping along the road. My teammates were still singing, yelling, doing their thing. I tried my best to concentrate. I thought about lacing my shoes, putting on my uniform, listening to my coachâ€™s pregame speech. I imagined walking out onto the court and how bright the lights would be. I imagined someone yelling at me from the crowd. I tried to envision how the ball would feel on my first jump shot. I could see their best player, a guy we had scouted, and I went over his go-to moves in my head.

When the van jolted to a stop, I realized we were at the arena. I was ready to go.

It was a close game all the way. With about 40 seconds left, I tied it with a three. The other team came down and missed two free throws. But on our next trip down, we missed and they got the ball back. They called a timeout with five seconds left. Tie game.

Looking back, I think about how calm I was. My mind wasnâ€™t racing. I felt focused. When they took the ball out, I got a jump on the passing lane and stole the ball. With just a few seconds left, I had to pull up from half court. Somehow, some way, the ball went in at the buzzer. We went on to the city finals.

The reason I think of that game isnâ€™t really because of my game-winning shot. Making the shot was nice, but I was more proud of the steal. I was locked in at just the right time.

I used to quiet my mind before games at Rupp Arena. I wanted to savor everything: The crazy student section, the alumni, the season ticket holders, blue and white everywhere. Kentucky fans are next level. Basketball is getting popular in Canada, but thereâ€™s a special type of Wildcat blue running through the veins of Kentucky fans. Itâ€™s not always easy quieting your mind with all that going on.

Coach Cal and Coach Payne are big reasons why I came to Kentucky. Their openness made it really easy to communicate with the coaching staff. A lot of people only know the guys they see on TV. As coaches, they can be fun and serious at the same time. Theyâ€™reÂ upbeat and animated, but also all business when they need to be. Above everything else, they treated us as family.Â

Lexington became my second home this year. The program is great about making us all feel part of the same family. To all the Kentucky fans that supported me, I loved playing in front of you. I fed off of your energy. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

Iâ€™m really going to miss my teammates and our traditions. During the Ohio State game this year, I hit a three and I was running back on D. I looked over at the bench and my teammate EJ was pretending to shoot a bow and arrow. The next time I hit a three, I copied what he did. You wind your right arm back like youâ€™re pulling back an arrow, then you let it go. Our whole bench started to do it whenever we hit a three. A tradition, and a new nickname, had been born.

Next year Iâ€™ll definitely be watching the team and following their success. I know theyâ€™ll do big things and create new traditions of their own.

As I move on to the NBA draft, itâ€™s a big unknown out there. I know I canâ€™t control everything, but I will remain just as focused on my mental game as on my physical game. In crunch time, I want to guard the other teamâ€™s best player. I want the ball for the last shot.

Iâ€™m looking forward to seeing what bullseye I can hit next, blindfolded or not.

item.title: The Objective
item.author: Ahmad Bradshaw
item.description: One win isnâ€™t a streak, but itâ€™s a start. The mission is clear, and the objective is in our sights: Beat Navy.
item.keywords: AFC Bournemouth,An,Andy King,Basic,Big,Challenge,Character,Danny Collins,Dress,Emre Can,Ever,Finish,Fix,Game,George Friend,Goals,Group,James Collins,Joshua King,K,Kevin Long,Kid,Leon Best,Lewis Cook,Liam Moore,Look,Lost,Lucky,Mean,Morning,New,NighT,Once,Only,Part,Perform,Pride,Ran,Recognize,Remember,Sam Field,Shane Long,Shopping,Simon Moore,Slow,Steve Cook,Summer,TO,Test,West,bit,fate,somebody
item.content:encoded:
The first time I played football, I pretty much hated it.

I was nine years old and my best friend, Sebastian Moore, and I joined the Mighty Men, the local youth team that practiced at Dunbar High School on the corner of 29th and King on the South Side of Chicago. Sebastianâ€™s momÂ told us that going out for football would be a good way to keep busy and stay out of trouble. And so there we were on the first day of practice, standing in lines as we waited to perform mundane drills in the hot sun.

And these lines wereÂ long. There must have been 50 kids out there. We were standing around for what seemed like forever, then we would only get to carry the ball once or twice. It was boring. It was hot. And the coaches kept yelling at us. I wanted to quit.

When I got home, I told my mother I was done. Even though going out for football wasnâ€™t even her idea, she wasnâ€™t going to let me give up after just one practice. My mother is one of the toughest people I know â€” and Iâ€™ve come across a lot of actual drill sergeants. I donâ€™t think sheâ€™s ever quit anything halfway through in her life. So she just gave me this look like,Â No, child. And then she said, â€œYouâ€™re going to practice tomorrow.â€

So I went every day for the rest of the summer. And man, I was miserable.

But I stuck with it, and three years later, when I was in the seventh grade, I realized that I actually kind of liked football. Now that didnâ€™t mean I was great at it. In fact, I was a pretty selfish player, only concerned about my own performance. I couldnâ€™t stand it when my teammates would fumble the ball. One day at practice I decided Iâ€™d had enough. I got up in their faces and yelled, â€œHow do you fumble the ball? All you gotta do is hold it! Stop letting people take it from you!â€

And then on the next play â€¦ I fumbled. I was so mad at myself that I punched the ground, which was hard packed dirt. It hurt a little bit, but I didnâ€™t think much of it. Luckily, my team recovered the ball. I was still fuming. But when we broke the huddle before our next play, I went to clap and a pain shot through my right hand. I took a handoff and couldnâ€™t hold on to the ball. When I went to show my coach my hand after the play, the knuckle on my little finger was floating by my wrist. It was a boxerâ€™s fracture.

Coach called my mom and she came to pick me up. She had been at the grocery store, and instead of taking me straight to the hospital, she went back to the store so she could finish shopping. She had me carrying water cases around behind the cart â€” she didnâ€™t have much sympathy for my broken knuckle, especially after she found out how it had happened.

At the hospital the doctor made me look away while he pulled my finger out and popped it back into place â€” but I was still peeking. That really left an impression on me. Iâ€™m generally pretty calm, but as I watched my hand contort, I realized there werenâ€™t many other things in life where making a mistake made me mad enough to punch the ground. It showed me just how much I cared â€” I was almost surprised by how much the game meant to me. That was the moment when I knew I would be a football player.

As I write this now, Iâ€™m so grateful that my mother made me stick with football. I never asked her why she didnâ€™t just take me straight to the hospital after I broke my knuckle, but Iâ€™m pretty sure she was trying to teach me her kind of lesson: In order to be great at football, or anything else, you have to be able to persevere when the going gets tough.

If you want to understand me you have to start with my mother. Her name is Kizzy Collins. Sheâ€™s one of the toughest people Iâ€™ve ever met.

She raised me as a single mom in Chicagoâ€™s Bronzeville neighborhood. It was rough. When I was a senior in high school, a friend of mine was shot and killed on his birthday. Too many kids that age from my neighborhood met the same fate. I could have easily gone down the wrong path, but there was no way my mom would let that happen.

She worked in the marketing department of theÂ Chicago TribuneÂ from eight to five every day. Then she would go to school to study marketing in the evenings and not come home until 10. We had a pitbull, Mecca, and it actually didnâ€™t know her because she was never home. He barked at her one day because he didnâ€™t recognize her, and she gave him away. Just like that. He was a nice dog, but like I said: My mom is a tough lady.

She came to all of my games on the weekends when I was in middle school and high school. And if I had a game on Saturday sheâ€™d cook food beforehand for the kids to eat after they were done playing â€” just like all the other parents. I never thought about it when I was little, but now I appreciate what it took for her to do that after having worked so hard all week. Did she ever sleep?

Growing up, I lived in a two-bedroom apartment with my mother, my grandmother, Mona Collins, and my aunt, Nina Collins. My other aunt, Deneen Collins, and my two cousins lived in the apartment upstairs. Since my mom was at work all the time I spent a lot of my free time with them. My grandmother is the one who taught me how to play pretty much every sport â€” football, baseball, basketball and volleyball. She didnâ€™t really know the rules of football, but she would toss the ball around with me in the yard and let me run circles around her.

The four women who raised me are the reason I came to West Point (Kizzy Collins, Mona Collins, Nina Collins and Deneen Collins). For a long time I thought I would go to Wisconsin and play football, but I wanted to go to a school where I had a clear picture of what Iâ€™d be doing after graduation. I wanted to be able to take care of my family and help others. My mom helped me so much by working hard every day. Now itâ€™s my turn to do the same for her. Thatâ€™s my main goal in life.

I went to the U.S. Military Academy Prep School before I got to West Point. I was 18 years old, and my goal was to play football for Army. I knew it would be a challenge â€” that it would test me in ways Iâ€™d never been tested before â€” but I still wasnâ€™t fully prepared for what I experienced early on. I think thatâ€™s true of just about everyone who enrolls here, and it starts on Day One.

New cadets go to Cadet Basic Training at West Point in the summer before their freshman year. The first day is called R-Day, and itâ€™sÂ intense. One minute youâ€™re hugging your mom goodbye, and the next youâ€™re getting yelled at by upperclassmen. They tell you youâ€™re moving too slow, but then they yell at you if you start running, so you have to walk everywhere really fast. By the end of the day your head is bald, your face is shaved and youâ€™re marching in a parade in your dress uniform in front of your parents. Youâ€™re a completely different person. R-Day didnâ€™t really freak me out â€” Iâ€™d been getting screamed at by football coaches since the fourth grade â€” but there were some kids who were so scared that they started crying and got right back in the car with their parents and went home.

The moment where I wanted to quit didnâ€™t come until the next morning. At about 4:30, this group of cadets came running into our barracks yelling, â€œYouâ€™ve got two minutes to get on the wall!â€ I was so shaken. We were supposed to make our beds, get dressed and get on the wall inÂ two minutes.Â We were all outside in T-shirts and shorts. I thought that would be O.K. because it was summertime. But at 4:30 in the morning it was freezing. We stood there for 15 minutes in formation, just shivering. There was still dew on the grass when we started doing push-ups and sit-ups for our morning physical training, so now we were not only freezing, but also wet. It was so uncomfortable.

Playing Division I football is incredibly tough, but nothing compares to the challenge of making it as a cadet at West Point. Whenever I find myself struggling, I try to compare what Iâ€™m experiencing to a harder time that somebody I know has gone through. I have thought a lot lately about a family member of mine in Chicago. He was homeless and has since passed away. He stayed with us at our house for a while when I was a kid, but his pride was so big that he wouldnâ€™t stay for long â€” even though he didnâ€™t know where he was going to sleep the next night or when his next meal would be. I think of my friends from the South Side who lost their lives to gun violence. An early morning drill isnâ€™t much compared to those kinds of things.

During my time at the academy, the way I analyze situations has changed. Iâ€™ve learned to speak up when I see something wrong, no matter how big or small. I see it as my professional responsibility to fix issues. As a team captain, a lot of my teammates come to me for advice, and I owe it to them to be honest. I value these relationships and feel that I am in a better position to help them based on my development at the academy. I think speaking up and giving honest feedback are the keys to growth. West Point created an environment where I could develop into the sort of leader that the Army expects and deserves.

When I was just a kid on the South Side I knew I wanted to surround myself with friends, mentors and peers that have good character and high expectations for me. I found that at the academy and for that I am so thankful.

Iâ€™m so lucky to be here. To be at this school, to be on this team, to be coached by someone as smart and talented as Coach Monken. He is the main reason Army went from winning two games in 2015 to going undefeated at home this year and being in a position to win the Commander-in-Chiefâ€™s Trophy for the first time in 21 years. All weâ€™ve got left to do is beat Navy on Saturday â€” something weâ€™ve only done once in the last 15 years.

But beating them twice is another one of my goals.

We almost lost to the Midshipmen last year. They had scored early in the fourth quarter to go up 17â€“14. We got the ball with about 13 minutes to go. What I remember most is our determination. In past years, our team might have gotten down and concluded it just wasnâ€™t our year. But this was different. We looked at each other in the huddle and all the guys on the offensive line started grabbing each other and saying, â€œAll right, letâ€™s tighten up! We got this!â€

When our offense is working, itâ€™s because every single person on the field is doing their specific job well. Itâ€™s kind of beautiful when everything comes together and pretty much impossible to stop. When we walk up to the line of scrimmage, we know weâ€™re gonna run the ball, and the other team knows weâ€™re gonna run the ball, but we do it anyway. Our receivers are some of the most selfless teammates Iâ€™ve ever had. They know weâ€™re not going to throw the ball 15 to 30 times a game. But theyâ€™re still out there making blocks and playing just as hard as anybody else, with or without the ball.

On that drive against Navy, we held the ball for almost seven minutes. On second-and-eight from Navyâ€™s 12-yard line, I kept the ball and was running around the right edge, behind Andy Davidson, who was my lead blocker. I saw tackle Brett Toth seal the edge and in a split second I made a decision: I wasnâ€™t just gonna go for the first down, I was going all the way. Right before I got to the goal line I saw this guy from Navy waiting for me. I ran full speed and lowered my shoulder. I could feel guys kind of pushing me from the back to get those last few inches. I couldnâ€™t tell if I had made it into the end zone, but then I saw the referee signal a touchdown. Thatâ€™s when everything erupted. I couldnâ€™t even see faces. Just pure noise and excitement. We won 21â€“17.

That play was the play that broke Armyâ€™s 14-year losing streak against Navy. That was also the play that started a movement for Army football. It was a breakthrough. Ever since our team has had a different mind-set. Weâ€™re more confident, we know who we are, and we know what we need to do to win.

A big part of that, like I said, comes from Coach Monken. Heâ€™s gotten everybody to work together in a way only cadets could understand.Â Itâ€™s easy to be an individual in football. Like if I was a receiver and I just ran my routes and didnâ€™t worry about what the other receiver was doing on the other side of the field. But in the military, if I donâ€™t get a certain part of my mission done, it can have serious consequences. Everybody has to do their job, but everybody also has to be molded together.

This Saturday, Iâ€™m going to be playing in my final Army-Navy game. Itâ€™s the biggest game of my life and I know how big the stakes are. Honestly, thatâ€™s the coolest part about it. Everybody from Navy is watching, everybody from Army is watching, and soldiers all over the world are watching, too. Army-Navy is so much bigger than just two teams on a field.

One win isnâ€™t a streak, but itâ€™s a start. The mission is clear, and the objective is in our sights:

Beat Navy.

item.title: The NBA Draft Survival Guide
item.author: C.J. McCollum
item.description: Iâ€™ve hit YouTube pretty hard over the last few days to research some of these rookies, and hereâ€™s a few under-the-radar and or small school guys that I like.
item.keywords: Ashley Williams,AndrÃ© Green,Brian Howard,Dwight Howard,Danny Williams,Doug McDermott,Daniel Williams,Ben McLemore,Mike Conley,NCAA Tournament,Shane Long,Portland Trail Blazers,Nerlens Noel,NBA Draft,Matt Green,Lewis Dunk,Kevin McDonald,Jonathan Williams,Tom Carroll,Shaun Williams,Ryan Williams,Reece Brown,Lou Williams,Jonny Williams,Izzy Brown
item.content:encoded:
Donâ€™t believe everything you hear. Thatâ€™s my advice to the NBA Draft Class of 2015. In this day and age, thereâ€™s a lot of chatter about guys being â€œlocksâ€ for certain teams. A lot of that stuff isnâ€™t just coming out of thin air. Teams will literally tell you to your face in the days before the Draft, â€œIf youâ€™re there, weâ€™re taking you.â€ But the reality is that crazy things can happen when the dominos start falling on Thursday night.

I was sitting in the green room during the 2013 Draft, and I was pretty much chillinâ€™ because I had a couple teams in the Top 10 who said they would take me. But at the same time, itâ€™s kind of a weird situation because you have your entire life packed up in a few suitcases back at the hotel room, and depending on what happens over the course of a few hours, you could be taking those bags on a flight anywhere. Your whole life is genuinely hanging in the balance. So itâ€™s super exciting, but also surreal.

When the Draft started and David Stern walked up to podium, I thought for sure I was going to Sacramento. They had the No. 7 pick, and asked me to fly back to Sac for a second workout to take a closer look. But then when I saw Nerlens Noel slide to Philadelphia, I immediately started seeing the puzzle pieces shift in my head. Sure enough, Sacramento took Ben McLemore at 7. Apparently, he was No. 1 on their Draft board, but they didnâ€™t think he was going to be there. So itâ€™s a good thing I didnâ€™t show up to the draft in a purple suit. Detroit and Minnesota were up next, and my name wasnâ€™t called. Over the course of 15 minutes, youâ€™re envisioning yourself in all these different jerseys and all these different cities.

My phone was blowing up with all kinds of texts but there was only one that I knew was for real â€” it was from Damian Lillard. It just said, â€œUh oh.â€

Dame and I had been Internet Friends through Twitter for, like, two years. We were both scorers from small schools, and Dame was leading the country in scoring at Weber State for most of the 2011-2012 season. I was third or fourth. So somehow we connected through a mutual friend. Then, when he got picked by Portland that year, it was really encouraging to me. Thatâ€™s when I knew I could be a lottery pick coming out of Lehigh. So we would text one another about basketball stuff all throughout my senior year, but we had never met in person up until the NBA Draft Lottery event in New York City. I saw him standing there, and it was super funny because it felt like some online dating thing where you finally meet the person for real. Itâ€™s like, â€œHey, bro, weâ€™ve been talking forÂ years. Nice to meet you.â€

So when he texted me â€œUh oh,â€ I got excited because I knew exactly what he meant. We had been talking about how cool it would be to play together for months. When I was taking my meetings with teams around the country, I posted three cities on my Instagram that I really liked. I didnâ€™t tell anybody what it meant â€” it was just kind of an inside thing. Portland was one of those cities. Actually, I remember getting to Portland, and being introduced to all kinds of organic food and shopping at New Seasons Market. I was a No. 2 guy at Lehigh. Get home from practice and hit the No. 2 meal at McDonaldâ€™s with no pickle. Now, Iâ€™m out here eating meals I struggle to pronounce.

The next couple minutes were a blur. David Stern walked up to the podium and announced my name, and I mean,Â damn. To be able to hug my mom, dad, my brother, GMA, and walk up on that stage and put on the hat, it was really a dream come true.

Now, you have to remember, Iâ€™m coming from Lehigh, so I didnâ€™t have some crazy advance. Iâ€™m still broke, for real. So that night I just remember enjoying as many free drinks (non-alcoholic, of course) as I possibly could. Thatâ€™s the crazy thing about the NBA Draft parties â€” everything is comped! Thatâ€™s a real savior for the mid-major guys who have all their boys coming to celebrate with them. So I actually have two pieces of advice for NBA Draftees: Donâ€™t believe everything you hear, and be sure to take advantage of the free drinks. New York is expensive.

After that night, everything moves really fast, depending on whether or not your team wants you in town the following day for a press conference. You grab your bags and youâ€™re on a plane to your team. When I got to Portland, and they gave me my jersey and my first pair of real NBA socks with the Jerry West logo, that was crazy. I donâ€™t know why but Iâ€™ve been thinking about getting those thick-ass NBA socks since I was a little kid. Theyâ€™re like walking on clouds.

*

I didnâ€™t have too much time to watch NCAA ball this season but Iâ€™ve hit YouTube pretty hard over the last few days to research some of these rookies, and here are a few under-the-radar and or small school guys that I like. (Yes, Iâ€™m biased towards guards.)

Cameron Payne
School:Â Murray State
Reminds me of:Â Damon Stoudamire

One of the knocks on Payne is quality of competition. All I can say to that is, look at who just won the NBA MVP. Steph Curry went to Davidson. One of the advantages of going to a small school is that youâ€™re expected to be the man. They have to give you the ball, and thereâ€™s more room for error in a situation where you can play your way through mistakes (and no matter how good you are, this is a valuable coping skill at the NBA level). Payne was the guy circled on the scouting report every single night. When youâ€™re coming from a mid-major program, a lot of teams donâ€™t want to schedule you for out-of-conference games if you have an NBA caliber player on your roster, because they essentially have to pay your school for the opportunity to come in and whoop their ass.

I started following Payne after I heard about this smooth lefty who had led Murray State to 25 wins in a row. Yes, he can shoot. But what I like about him is that heâ€™s got a good hesitation move, nice change of speed and a floater, which I think is going to be key for him at 6â€™2â€ in the NBA. If Iâ€™m Payne, Iâ€™m watching a lot of film on Mike Conley, another lefty. Conley can finish with both hands and he has theÂ best righty floaterÂ Iâ€™ve ever seen for a left-handed guy.

Everything in the NBA is sped up. Lanes close much faster than college. So itâ€™s about having a very balanced skill set as a guard, and Payne has that package of shooting, passing and slashing. Heâ€™s also 180, so heâ€™s going to need to put on some pounds, but the facilities and weight rooms in the NBA are going to be so far beyond what he had at Murray State, so I wouldnâ€™t worry about it. You can transform your body pretty quickly with 24/7 nutrition and trainers.

I also like Payne because he wasnâ€™t even ranked by any scouting services in high school. I remember my junior year, before I was getting any hype, I used to tell scouts that I was being recruited by random mid-majors. â€œOh yeah, Iâ€™m talking to uh â€¦ Youngstown State.â€ I figured they would never actually call and check. And even if they did, the Youngstown State coach might be afraid to get beat to the punch and be like, â€œHmm â€¦ whoâ€™s this McCollum kid? I better check him out.â€

You gotta hustle.

R.J. Hunter
School:Â Georgia State
Reminds me of:Â Rip Hamilton

Similar to Payne, heâ€™s a lean guy from a small school who can really ball. With Hunter, what I notice is his ability to pull up and hit big-time shots from anywhere on the floor. With what he did to Baylor in the NCAA Tournament, heâ€™s proven that he has the clutch gene. Some of the threes he hit were very, very deep, and off the dribble.

You look at the team who just won the NBA title and you see a bunch of guys who have a very quick release who can shoot from anywhere. The NBA is evolving into a league where you have to be able to get up-and-down, shoot threes and play multiple positions. This is the kind of guy that players want on their team. Â Hunter is only a 6â€™5â€ two-guard, but he has almost a 6â€™10â€ wingspan. Quick release + long wingspan = a guy who can contribute right away.

Shooting is the one thing that always translates seamlessly to the NBA level, but I will say that R.J. is going to find that itâ€™s a lot harder to shoot from deep when youâ€™re tired. In college, the line is so close that you can kind of half-heartedly shoot the ball off-balance and fading away. To shoot an NBA three, because the arc of your shot has to be a little higher, you have to be squared up and get your legs into it more, which can be tough in the fourth quarter.

With R.J., itâ€™s not just that he can shoot, he canÂ move,Â which is why I see some Rip Hamilton in him. He can curl into the lane and finish with the floater, which is essential for an undersized guard. At 180 or 190, youâ€™re not going to be able to get to the hoop and dunk in the NBA. Itâ€™s just impossible to take that beating night in, night out. Bigs hate the floater because they canâ€™t contest it â€” itâ€™s too quick and itâ€™s all about touch. R.J. should watch how Steph Curry has implemented an overhand and underhand floater into his repertoire. I donâ€™t care how many pounds he puts on, R.J. is going to need to pull that out of the bag of tricks when he sees Dwight Howard in the lane.

Anthony Brown
School:Â Stanford
Reminds me of:Â DeMarre Carroll

I got some inside info here because I worked out with him last year when I was in L.A. (we use the same trainer, AJ Diggs). Heâ€™s a 6â€™7â€ small forward with a great wingspan who might be one of the best shooters in the draft (44% from three in his last two seasons). Heâ€™s also a senior who went to Stanford, so you know youâ€™re going to get a smart, mature guy in your locker room right away.

Heâ€™s a classic three-and-D player. Right now it looks like heâ€™ll be a fringe first rounder, but with the new deal coming in â€™16, itâ€™s almost sometimes better to go second round than late first. Second rounders get fewer guaranteed years, which means you can hit the market faster. Of course, we can project all we want, but you never know whatâ€™s gonna happen in the NBA with some of these guys. A lot of times, whether a player fits with a team is as big a factor in determining their fate at their skill level. If Brown finds the right spot, I think heâ€™ll stick around in this league a long time. When you have an almost seven-foot wingspan and can guard multiple positions, youâ€™re going to get minutes. The long wingspan combined with good lateral quickness will allow him to sag off screens and still be able to contest shots. (Fighting over screens in the NBA is tough. Remind me to tell you all my horror stories about guarding Lou Williams some day.)

I like his game and his attitude, and I can see him becoming a big X-factor for a winning team on both ends of the floor â€” similar to DeMarre Carroll in Atlanta. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s always so interesting about the NBA Draft â€” all the hype is about the franchise guys at the top, but I can just see Brown going to the Warriors at 30 and everyone kind of ignoring it. But then, in three years, heâ€™ll be making a huge difference guarding a superstar and hitting big spot-up threes in the Finals.

*

Letâ€™s do a few more quick ones. I havenâ€™t seen as much of these guys.

Tyler Harvey
School:Â Eastern Washington
Reminds me of:Â Gary Neal

Tyler led the country in scoring last season, which is always worth a look. Recent NBA players that led the NCAA in scoring include Doug McDermott, Reggie Williams and Steph Curry. One of the things about Harvey that impressed me is that he had a true shooting percentage of over 60 percent, so heâ€™s efficient. He also shot over 40 percent from three. He just has a great scoring sense and can get up shots in a hurry, and catch fire just as quickly. At 6â€™4â€, 180 lbs., I think itâ€™s going to be interesting to see how his game translates to the NBA, but I like what he did in college. Heâ€™s definitely someone to keep an eye on during the summer league. His ability to score is something that could translate.

Olivier Hanlan
School:Â Boston College
Reminds me of:Â Marcus Thornton

Like Tyler, Olivier is a guy who specializes in scoring and could be some instant offense in the NBA. He went to Boston College for three years, and showed improvement every season. He also averaged 19.5 points against tough competition in the ACC. The best way to describe his style of play is smooth. He looks natural out there. He did well at the combine with his ability to create in the pick and rolls, and for that reason as much as anything else I think heâ€™ll stick on someoneâ€™s roster.

Richaun Holmes
School:Â Bowling Green
Reminds me of:Â Too early to say at this point

Iâ€™m throwing this in here as my super sleeper. I saw Richaun work out for the Blazers last week, and came away impressed. Heâ€™s a late-blooming, athletic power forward. He started out at a community college when he was a freshman but showed noticeable improvement every year at Bowling Green, and was named the defensive player of the year in the MAC this past season. He had a pretty good PER too.

The thing that will have teams intrigued is his great footwork and timing. He can contest shots very well, but what also caught my eye was his ability to knock down shots. He shot over 40 percent from three last season, but heâ€™s 6â€™10â€ so he didnâ€™t take a lot of threes because they needed him in the paint. Heâ€™s very skilled, a little raw, but heâ€™s an NBA-level athlete. I think heâ€™s a sleeper guy who can surprise some people.

item.title: Itâ€™s the Fighters Who Make It
item.author: Richarlison
item.description: I came a long way to get here, and I donâ€™t want to stop now.

media:thumbnail.caption: Richarlison, Brazilian professional footballer who plays as a forward for Premier League club Everton and the Brazilian national team. | Sam Robles/The Players' Tribune

item.content:encoded:
Para ler em PortuguÃªs, clique aqui.

I want to tell you a fishing story.Â

When I was 17 years old and living in Brazil, I went to visit my dad for the weekend with my two brothers and my cousins. My dad, AntÃ´nio, was not having an easy time. He had been separated from my mum, Vera Lucia, for 10 years, and was living on a farm on his own. Worse, he was suffering from depression.Â

I was very attached to him, in part because he had always believed in my dream to become a footballer. He would go anywhere to watch me play. Of course I wanted to be a pro.Â

Yet the only thing I had achieved was a long list of rejections.Â

In fact I was running out of time to get my big break. I was training with the youth team of AmÃ©rica-MG, one of the biggest clubs in the state of Minas Gerais. Even though I was already old by youth academy standards, I was still trying to get a contract.

So I knew this was my last chance.Â

Anyway, on this particular weekend the team had been given some time off, and since I was living with my mum, it was only natural to spend some time with Dad. While we were at his place, my brothers and cousins and I grabbed our fishing rods and headed out to these three ponds near the house. They must have been on the same piece of land, because the landlord had said that we were only allowed to fish in two of them. The third pond was forbidden.Â

So we spent the entire day fishing in the two ponds. And we got nothing.Â

To be honest, we didnâ€™t really care. We were only there to have fun. But on the way back to the house, we walked past the Forbidden Pond. We looked at each other. We looked at the pond. Nobody else seemed to be watching. We still had some bait leftâ€¦.Â

And so I hooked on a piece and tossed it into the water.Â

Two seconds laterâ€¦.Â

SNAP!

Fish on.Â

Iâ€™m still not sure why I did it. Anyway, it was stupid, because the landlord eventually found out about it. He went to my dad and shouted at him in front of a group of people, saying he could kick him out of his house any time he wanted.Â

It was the last thing my dad needed. He was humiliated.

And in that moment, something clicked inside my head. I remember telling my Uncle Elton, â€œI will do anything to get a contract at AmÃ©rica. Iâ€™m gonna get my dad out of there.â€Â

Before that, helping my family through football had been just an idea.Â

Suddenly it was an obsession.Â

Looking back, I guess I was bound to grow attached to my dad the moment he gave me a bunch of footballs for my birthday. There is no better way to win the loyalty of a Brazilian kid. At the time, my family was living together in a wooden house in Todos os Santos, a little village in the state of EspÃ­rito Santo, near the Brazilian coast. There was a football pitch close to our home where I used to play with my friends. When I was not there, Iâ€™d be out watching my dad play for his local team. Wherever my dad went â€” whether he was playing cards or seeing his friends in the town square â€” he would take me with him.Â

When I was seven, my parents broke up. Dad was going to Minas Gerais to work, and the rest of us â€” me, Mum and my two brothers and my two sisters â€” were going to Nova VenÃ©cia. That was where I started my dream, really, because I enrolled at a football school there. On the first day I turned up with butterflies in my stomach. I was already fantasising about playing for the SeleÃ§Ã£o. I owned a Brazil shirt. I would watch all the World Cups and the qualifiers. I had no bigger dream than to put on the yellow jersey.Â

On that morning we were playing on a clay pitch. It was so much fun, and the coach liked me. Over the next few months I trained harder and harder. I also realised that football was not just a career path for me. It could also help my family. We were five people living in a house with two rooms in total, and my mum was working every day to make sure we had enough to eat. She is such a fighter. But she couldnâ€™t do it all on her own, and pretty soon she began asking us to help her out.Â

So when I was 11, I got a job. I began selling ice pops.

Look, I know it sounds random. But for me it was a natural thing to do. My great-granddad was famous in the town for selling them. For years he had been sitting in the square with his cart. Now he was running his little business with my cousin, so during the summers I would join him. Iâ€™d get up at 6 a.m., wheel the cart downtown and spend the day shouting like one of those match-day programme sellers you see outside the football stadiums. â€œIce pops! Ice pops! Get yer ice pops here!â€

I always made sure to walk past the houses that had the most children. What kid doesnâ€™t like an ice pop? But even though I sold a lot, I didnâ€™t earn much. So I had to do other jobs, too, to help my mum. I sold chocolate candies that my aunt had made.Â

And then there was the car wash.Â

Oh man, the car washâ€¦.Â

Look, I thought it was going to be an easy job. How hard could it be, right? Well, it turned out to be brutal. I was spending entire days soaping up muddy tires and scrubbing dirty windshields. By the time my shift was over my body was aching. It was killing me!Â

At one point my boss actually wanted to give me the job full-time. I was like, â€œSorry man, this isnâ€™t for me!â€ I never came back.Â

I also helped out my granddad on the farm. We would stay out all day in what felt like 50Â°C, harvesting coffee. I used to sweat and toil so much I was nearly crying! Then I would look over at my granddad and he was having the time of his life. I was like, How is it possible?!Â

But seriously, I admired his work ethic. It was inspiring. He, too, was a fighter.Â

He taught me other stuff as well. Sometimes I would hide from him, because I knew heâ€™d tell me off for hanging out with â€¦ well, letâ€™s just say they were the wrong kind of people. There was a lot of crime and drugs in my area, and I had some friends who were involved in it. When my mum was out working, I would go with one of my brothers out in the streets. We saw guns, bags full of money â€¦ we saw it all. Thank God, I never went looking for anything in that world. But one time that world came looking for me.

It happened when I was 14. I was walking home with a friend after having played football. It was about 8 p.m., so it was dark. Suddenly these two crazy guys came out of nowhere and pointed guns at us.

We were scared as hell. If one had pulled the trigger, even accidentally, weâ€™d have been dead.Â

We tried to explain the situation. Basically they thought we were trying to sell things in their spot. We showed them the ball we were carrying and said that we were just on our way home. Perhaps they had mistaken us for someone else. Anyway, after a very tense spell, they let us go.

Afterwards we tried to make light of it saying things like, â€œDude, you nearly s**t your pants back there.â€ We were still just kids, making fun of everything.

In any case, after all my experiences in Nova VenÃ©cia, I realised I had no choice. I wanted nothing to do with drugs. I wasnâ€™t a farmer. Selling ice pops wasnâ€™t my thing. And I sure as hell wasnâ€™t gonna go back to the car wash.

Basically, I couldn't see myself doing anything other than playing football.Â

Not that I needed to tell my friends that. They understood it once they saw my football shirt collection. I was walking around with the colours of Chelsea and Milan, I had the jerseys of Drogba and IbrahimoviÄ‡.Â

And Neymar, of course. Neymar was my idol. I had his Santos shirt. On the pitch I tried to pull off his moves. I played in his position. I even copied his hairstyle.Â

You know the yellow mohawk? I had that one!Â

But wanting to be Neymar is one thing, another is to actually play as a pro. So in 2013, when I was 15, I began looking for a contract.Â

I first spent a month on trial with AvaÃ­, a team in FlorianÃ³polis, some 1,800 kilometres down the coast from Nova VenÃ©cia. The way these things work is that you stay at the academy full-time, train hard and hope that theyâ€™ll give you a deal. The competition is so intense. At AvaÃ­ I went to bed with bruised shins almost every day. Then, after four weeks, a guy from the club told us that they werenâ€™t going to be taking in any new players after all. So, yeah â€¦ thanks. All that work for nothing.Â

What can you say? It was just a huge injustice.

I had a second trial lined up with Figueirense, in the same city. I had so little money left that I had to borrow boots from someone at the club. Again, I put my life on the line in training. Even though I was supposed to be there for only a week, the coach invited me for a second week. I was competing with nine other kids for one of two spots. In the end I spent another month running and fighting to get noticed.

And then Figueirense rejected me, too.Â

And when did I get the news?

On my 16th birthday.Â Â

I was devastated. I felt as if nothing was working out. I remember receiving all these jolly greetings from friends and family â€” â€œHappy birthday! :-Dâ€ â€” and yet all I could think about was that I had to go back to my mum in Nova VenÃ©cia. The trials were over.

I had to go looking for another job.

To be honest, I might have thrown in the towel if I hadnâ€™t had people around to support me. My dad was one of them. My granddad was another. Then there was Fidel â€” a police officer and a football coach â€” who I had played a lot of futsal with. â€œNever give up,â€ he said. Another one was Regis, who ran the football school. He had some good contacts, and one day he found a new team for me: Real Noroeste, a club close to Nova VenÃ©cia that was playing in the EspÃ­rito Santo state championship.Â

So I played for them for a year, and I evolved a lot.Â

But then they treated me very badly.Â

I had developed so much that year that AmÃ©rica-MG wanted to sign me. They were a bigger club and I wanted to go there. The guys from Real Noroeste told my dad that there would be no problem with my transfer. But then they demanded half of the fee. They were saying one thing and doing another. It was a huge issue for my dad. We both knew AmÃ©rica would be my last chance to make it, and their youth team had only four matches left of the season. For him to have to sort that out under that sort of pressure, at a time when he was struggling with depression â€¦ it hurt me a lot. I made some good friends at Real Noroeste, but to this day I donâ€™t like to talk too much about that club.Â

In any case, I went to AmÃ©rica for a final shot at a contract. I guess the trial could have ended with another rejection. I donâ€™t know. One thing I am sure of, though, is that after we went on that fishing trip and my dad was humiliated, I got another source of motivation. I found a gear I didnâ€™t know I had.Â

So I began training even harder. The goals started to fly in. The coaches took notice.Â

And in December 2014, I was offered a contract by AmÃ©rica.Â

Itâ€™s hard to describe the feeling when you finally get something you have chased for so long. I had been through so much pain and so many setbacks. Now I was finally able to help my family. My mum no longer had to worry. My dad could quit his job.Â

And I could play and train without worrying so much. First I made the AmÃ©rica first team. Then in 2016 I signed for Fluminense, one of the biggest clubs in Brazil. That enabled me to buy my first house, in Nova VenÃ©cia.

Thanks to God, it all worked out.Â

After that break my motivation shifted. The fishing story had driven me for a long time. Now I was focusing more on what had initially motivated me as a kid: playing for Brazil.Â

Moving to Europe was important. In 2017, when I was 20, I signed for Watford. Many people doubted that I could make it in the Premier League because a lot of Brazilians struggle when they first come over. But I never felt that pressure. I was just happy to be there.Â

Instead, the real issues took place off the pitch.Â

The language was one; I spoke no English. The weather was another. When I arrived it was sunny, so it felt like Brazil, but in November I could no longer feel my toes when I was playing, and by Christmas I had lost contact with my hands. That was tough, especially for someone who had never seen snow before.

Then there was the food. For the first two weeks I stayed in a hotel with my agent and his wife. In the morning we went downstairs to eat and ... well, letâ€™s just say that in Brazil, weâ€™re not used to fries for breakfast. In fact, the food was so strange to me that I skipped breakfast altogether. I started a diet of two meals a day. The menu? Burgers and Coca-Cola. They were the only things I was familiar with.

I ate like that for two weeks. I lost five kilos.Â

Thankfully I eventually adapted, and I want to give a big thank you to Heurelho Gomes, my best friend at Watford, who helped me so much. Obrigado. I still remember the first time I played against Manchester City, and not just because we lost 6â€“0 at home! I was so special to stand next to their players in the tunnel before the game â€” stars like Sergio AgÃ¼ero and Kevin De Bruyne. They were players I had met only in video games, and now I was about to play against them. Honestly, I felt like a little kid again.Â

Anyway, I did well enough in one season at Watford to get a move to Everton. And then, just a month later, I got my first call-up for Brazil.Â

I had been hoping for a call because I had started off well at Everton. I remember watching the squad announcement on TV. My name was not there, but I was like, Thatâ€™s O.K, Iâ€™ll keep trying. My chance will come. Then Pedro, the winger, unfortunately got injured. Suddenly Professor Tite called me. I felt a strange sensation in my body. Iâ€™m not sure how to explain it. My heart was thumping. He asked me if I was ready. I was like, â€œProfessor, Iâ€™m ready! When do you need me??â€Â

When I turned up to join the squad, I felt like I had arrived on another planet. I thanked God for the opportunity. I couldnâ€™t believe I was about to put on the yellow shirt.Â

For my first two games, which were friendlies against the U.S. and El Salvador, I got the number 9 shirt. It felt twice as heavy as any other shirt I had worn because, you know, it used to belong to the main man, Ronaldo. Obviously thatâ€™s a little bit, I donâ€™t know â€¦ crazy.Â

Both games were special. The first because it was my debut, and I got to play the last 15 minutes. The second because I started up front next to Neymar â€” and I scored two goals.

Playing with Neymar was incredible. I had met him once before, in his house in Paris, but I had only had time to take a picture with him. This time we were sharing the pitch. I had already told him that Iâ€™d once copied his yellow mohawk.Â

He just burst into laughter.Â

Now we are great friends. He always looks for me when he has the ball, and I feel we can become a great duo. It was a shame that he could not take part when we won the Copa AmÃ©rica last year. But the next World Cup will be another for us to win a trophy together. I just want to make sure we keep winning in the qualifiers and get there in good shape.

Until that happens, I just want to do my best for Everton. Sometimes my friends ask me if I miss Brazil and my family. Even though my life is great on Merseyside, of course I do.Â

But I came a long way to get here, and I donâ€™t want to stop now. There are millions of Brazilian kids who are trying to go the same way.

To those kids I just want to repeat the advice that I got five years ago.Â

Never give up.Â

Itâ€™s the fighters who make it.Â

Save Pantanal

Now that I have told you one story, you might as well hear another.Â Â

After I had finished the season with Watford in 2018, I went straight on holiday with some friends. We went camping and fishing in Brazil.Â

One of the areas we visited was Pantanal, in the southwestern state of Mato Grosso do Sul. Pantanal is famous for being the biggest tropical wetland in the world â€” a beautiful place, full of rare plants and animals. At one point during the trip, we drove past a village, and when we spotted a group of kids playing football there, we stopped the car and asked if we could join them. I feel fortunate that I got to play with them. Before we left I gave a football shirt to the village chief.

I spent nearly a week in Pantanal and had so much fun. I would recommend that place to anyone.Â

That is, whatever is left of it nowâ€¦.Â

I want to speak about something that matters a lot to me, and that should matter a lot to you, too. Iâ€™m sad and worried about what has happened to Pantanal. About a quarter of the whole region has been on fire this year. In the beginning I was seeing it on the news all the time, which made sense â€” itâ€™s an area we should all fight to protect.Â

But I didnâ€™t see anyone doing anything about it.Â

Which raises the question: Why?Â

Look, Iâ€™m not a politician. I canâ€™t stop the fires on my own. But as a player for Brazil and Everton, I can show people whatâ€™s going on. So I have posted a few pictures on social media in support of Pantanal. Not just to show sympathy, but to make the authorities wake up.Â

Right now there is way too much greed in politics. Some people do whatever they can to win elections, but once they have power they just exploit it for their own gain. And that ends up harming Brazil. I want the authorities to know that we are concerned about our country and its natural resources.Â Â

Some of my Everton teammates asked me about Pantanal when they saw the posts. I showed them some more pictures of the fires and they were shocked. They all knew about the wildlife in Brazil, but they didnâ€™t know about the dangers it was facing.Â

Guys, let me be clear here: It is very bad.Â

So I hope, through posts and campaigns, that we can all mobilise enough people to make the authorities wake up and do more to save the wetlands. People with many followers need to speak out. People who have authority need to use it.Â

The earth is our greatest treasure. Letâ€™s make sure we take care of it.Â

item.title: The Objective
item.author: Killian Hayes
item.description: An objective is something you cross off a list â€” something you know you can do.
item.keywords: NBA,France,NBA Draft,NBA Draft Lottery,Tony Parker,Killian Hayes
item.content:encoded:
At the Universal CityWalk in Orlando, there used to be an NBA store. It might as well have been heaven when I was six years old. There was a LeBron statue out front. It was huge. On the inside there were rows and rows of NBA jerseys, and balls stacked from the floor to the ceiling â€” and I wanted to touch them all. I remember just going from aisle to aisle, grabbing each jersey and turning it around to see the name on the back.

JAMES

BRYANT

NOWITZKI

Iâ€™d call my dad over to show him my favorite ones. I could have spent all day there. That place was special because we didnâ€™t have anything like it back home in France. My parents and I came to America every summer during my dadâ€™s off-season. He played pro basketball for Cholet, just outside of Nantes. When his season would end weâ€™d head back to where Dad grew up, in the Central Florida area, and Iâ€™d get to live for a few months as an American kid.

I was born in Florida, yes, but I was raised in France.

In Cholet, the NBA felt like it was a million miles away.

Every day, when I got out of elementary school, Mum would come pick me up at four oâ€™clock and take me home. Iâ€™d rush through my homework and then wait until nobody was using our family computer, and then Iâ€™d get on the Internet. Thatâ€™s how I used to learn about the NBA. On YouTube, Iâ€™d watch hours and hours of And1 mixtapes and highlight videos of my guys, like Dwyane Wade and Bron. If I could go back and check my Internet history from back then, Iâ€™m sure it would be just pages and pages of links like, â€œBEST CROSSOVERS 2008/09â€ and â€œJUMPER COMPILATION NBA.â€

I rarely, if ever, saw a full game. So to me, those players were literal human highlight reels who were capable of doing anything on the court.

Thatâ€™s why, when we walked into the NBA store in Orlando, seeing their jerseys was like touching Supermanâ€™s cape, or something like that.

My favorite part, though, was the hand imprints they had on the wall. They had Kobe and Bron on there, but the wildest one was Shaq â€” no doubt. I think I could have fit five of my hands inside his palm. He was a big deal in Orlando, too, of course. There were pictures of him all over the store, and his jersey was everywhere.

NBA basketball made me proud to have been born there.

Because I had been born in the States, and my dad was from there, I felt like I was a part of American basketball. Like I was closer to it than all the kids I played with back in France. Even as a seven- or eight-year-old boy, I was always proud to introduce myself in class as Killian Hayes, from Lakeland, Florida.

Cholet isnâ€™t that big of a place. My elementary school was near our house, and most of the kids lived in the same neighborhood. When I wasnâ€™t watching NBA highlights after school, Iâ€™d be out at the field playing soccer with my friends. I never played on any organized teams â€” because once I put my hand inside Shaqâ€™s, I knew I wanted to play basketball forever â€” but everyone in town played soccer, so thatâ€™s what I did. And in class, all the kids would talk about Ronaldo and Messi, not Bron and Kobe.

But one thing I want to make clear is this: France is absolutely a basketball country, too.

We might not have the international pedigree of other European countries, and certainly not the U.S., but there is a great basketball culture in France.

I learned that from going to my dadâ€™s games in Cholet.

The atmosphere at those games was more like a Champions League soccer match than it was an NBA game. The crowds were loud, and they were smart. They respected the crisp, dagger bounce pass just as much as they loved the dunk.

The atmosphere at those games was more like a Champions League soccer match than it was an NBA game.

When Mum was busy, Iâ€™d go to my dadâ€™s practices from time to time after school, and I learned a lot there. Dad would lower the hoop for me and pick me up and let me dunk. As I got a bit older, heâ€™d run me through drills. Heâ€™s a big guy, 6 '6" and 230 pounds. So for a long time he was pretty stiff competition. I couldnâ€™t post him up until a few years ago.

He pushed me hard, but he never forced me to play basketball.

Dad had played college ball in the States, and I knew his journey hadnâ€™t been straightforward. He never made it to the league and he had to grind really hard in Europe to make a name for himself. He knows the game of basketball â€” and the world of basketball â€” more than most people.

I think he knew that if I wanted to do this, like if I really wanted to try to be a basketball player, then I had to love it. I had to love coming to the gym each day. I had to love the process. And when I got to be 11 or 12 years old, he saw that in me. I was a determined boy. When Iâ€™d come back to America in the summers, and weâ€™d go down to the rec center and Iâ€™d play against some really good players who were older than me, thatâ€™s when I knew I could play this game.

My dream wasnâ€™t just to play basketball forever.

All those YouTube videos and trips to the CityWalk had left a mark on me.

My dream was to play in the NBA.

But the road from Cholet to the NBA draft was hard to navigate.

When I was 14, my dad was considering coming back to Florida to try to play professionally. So we also talked about me going to one of the big high schools in the States to get myself ready for college ball.

And I wanted that, real bad. I had seen so many videos online of the McDonaldâ€™s All American games and the big AAU tournaments and all those different youth basketball events. There was so much hype, and all those guys were choosing between different colleges to go to â€” it just seemed like the dream. But my parents and I did a lot of talking about the best route to take going forward, and it didnâ€™t include going to America.

A part of me was a bit disappointed when we came to the decision, but I understood. I trusted my dad and his experience with the high school and college system in America. Itâ€™s not that itâ€™s bad or canâ€™t produce great players â€” lots of superstar players go through it â€” but he just felt that for me, the most important thing was to learn how to be a great pro.

Heâ€™d say, â€œAll the five-star ratings, all the hype videos â€” they donâ€™t mean anything if you get to the NBA and canâ€™t make it work as a professional basketball player.â€

But at the end of the day, the decision was still mine. And with all of the options laid out in front of me, I decided to stay in France and become a professional player at Cholet.

I played my first game as a pro at 16 years old. Most kids that age are juniors in high school, but there I was going up against grown men â€” playing for their livelihoods, in games that truly mattered to the clubs. The teams in France rely on the prize money for making the playoffs and the gate proceeds to stick around, so each game really matters. It made me see the game a bit differently.

There wasnâ€™t time to make mistakes, there wasnâ€™t time to play like a rookie.

There wasnâ€™t time to make mistakes, there wasnâ€™t time to play like a rookie.

When Iâ€™d hold on to the ball for too long, or try to make a play on my own, the coach would always yell at me. I had grown up being one of the better players on my junior teams, and Iâ€™d gotten used to forcing plays from time to time because I knew I had the ability to do it. But at the pro level, I couldnâ€™t do that.

Being on edge like that ... it made me uncomfortable. But I learned quickly that the best way to grow was to be uncomfortable. I got better as a player because I had to, because there was no other choice. I knew I wouldnâ€™t play much if I couldnâ€™t get into the lineup. My dad knew that, and I also think he knew that I would rise to the challenge.

I had to mature quickly. No time to complain about playing time, or who gets the ball when. We were in the business of winning games. That was what mattered.Â

My older teammates helped me out, on and off the court. I couldnâ€™t get my drivers license in France until I was 18, so my first few years with Cholet my parents and teammates used to have to drive me to and from practices and games. People always offered to help because they knew I cared so much about Cholet. I had been going to the arena since before I can remember. I knew the club really well. Itâ€™s one big family.

When I think of Cholet, I think of guys like Abdoulaye Ndoye and Warren Woghiren â€” who started their pro careers around the same time I did. They helped me so much in the weight room and on the court, and also helped me grow as a player and a professional. They showed me that I could do this, that I could be a pro. That was when the NBA changed for me from a dream to an objective.

That might sound the same to you, but itâ€™s not. A dream is something that you imagine, something you donâ€™t expect to happen. An objective is something you cross off a list â€” something you know you can do.

You just gotta go do it.

So in 2019, I took the next step in my career and decided to move away from home. I went to Germany to play for ratiopharm Ulm in the Basketball Bundesliga. It was a chance to test my game even more, to make myself more uncomfortable. We played in the EuroCup against some of the best teams from all over the continent. It was an incredible experience, a chance to see the game in different parts of the world â€” it was just really rewarding.

I used to watch March Madness highlights as a boy. The sold-out football stadiums going crazy for Duke and North Carolina â€¦ I thought it was just the coolest thing ever. Thatâ€™s why the decision to stay in Europe was tough. I wanted that college experience. But if I could go back in time and tell myself to have confidence in the choice, to keep the faith, I would talk about the places the game can take you.

I was 18 years old and playing pro basketball in Germany. I was travelling to Italy, Spain and all these other places to play a game. I learned more than I ever could have imagined and I have zero regrets about the path I was fortunate enough to take.

All of those experiences have prepared me for whatâ€™s next.

Iâ€™m ready to cross an objective off my list.

Iâ€™m ready to be a professional basketball player in the NBA.

Everything Iâ€™ve done in my life has been leading to this moment.

Everything Iâ€™ve done in my life has been leading to this moment.

Itâ€™s funny, I got a DM from Tony Parker the other day on Instagram. He was just saying hello and that he wanted to talk sometime, give me some advice. Heâ€™s obviously a legend and I was shocked to see it. But it made me realize something â€” or at least it made me think about something I used to dream about.

During all the interviews with the NBA teams before the draft, they would ask me about what type of player I wanted to be. I told them the truth â€” about the dream that had been with me since I was a little kid: I want to be a great pro, just like my dad taught me to be. I want to be a teammate who guys in the room can rely on. And I want to be a leader on the court.

But I also told them that I am incredibly proud of where I was raised.

I want to be one of the best players to come out of France, just like Tony.

Right now, itâ€™s a dream, too. But I know I can turn it into an objective.

item.title: How I Work
item.author: Buddy Hield
item.description: When Iâ€™m on the court, reggae helps me get into the right zone. All reggae. Only reggae.
item.content:encoded:
Youâ€™d like my workouts. Iâ€™ve always got the music blasting.

When Iâ€™m on the court, reggae helps me get into the right zone. All reggae. Only reggae.

Reggae reminds me of home. The Bahamas. Eight Mile Rock. Thatâ€™s my home and Iâ€™ll never forget it. Back there, weâ€™ve got our own reggae music. You might never have heard these tracks but if you spent a week with me, itâ€™d become your favorite music, too. I guarantee you.

Eight Mile Rock taught me about a lot of things in life, and one of those things is the energy you can get from music. Reggae has great beats, but more than anything it tells stories. It talks to me. It talks to me about my home and reminds me of the struggles that my six brothers and sisters all went through. It talks to me about the guys on the corners dealing drugs who never bothered me because they knew my mom (everyone knew my mom). It tells my story in a way that movies and books and other stories canâ€™t.

When Iâ€™m working out, my music reminds me that Iâ€™m happy and free to pursue my dreams. It makes me want to work that much harder because Iâ€™ve learned not to take anything for granted. Going through the draft process feels unreal to me. I used to watch the draft when I was a kid and it seemed so far away. I know how much work I have put in to get to the point where Iâ€™m have the opportunity to go to the NBA. I couldnâ€™t have done it without my family and God and a bunch of good people at my side.

I donâ€™t talk about my childhood so that you should feel sorry for me, but I do want to show people how motivated I am. I know how hard I work and how much I love this game.

Whatever situation I find myself in next year, Iâ€™m going to go as hard as I can. I want to compete with the best in the world.

But first, I want to enjoy this process. After I shake the commissionerâ€™s hand, Iâ€™ll be thinking about everybody from Eight Mile Rock whoâ€™s rooting and cheering for me. I see you guys. I know what type of music youâ€™ll be playing back home tonight. Turn it up for me.

***

item.title: What To Know Before You Jump
item.author: Wendell Carter Jr.
item.description: At a time when I was on the fence as to what I was going to do, it was actually Coach K who convinced me to make the leap.
item.content:encoded:
A few years ago, when I was going back and forth about whether to make the jump to the NBA after one season at Duke, I took a walk over to Coach Kâ€™s office.

I didnâ€™t know what to expect when I got there.

One of the things I knew about Coach from back in the day was that he wasnâ€™t a fan of the whole one-and-done thing. He wanted players to come to Duke and stay â€” ideally for a full four years. Then, when I got to campus in the fall of 2017, I talked to some guys whoâ€™d played at Duke before I got there and they told me about how Coach K would be fuming whenever players would leave early. So all that was the backdrop.

Anyway, I walk in, and sit down, andâ€¦.

It was like I was talking to a totally different person from the guy in those stories.

The first thing out of Coachâ€™s mouth was how he thought Iâ€™d had a great season. He told me Iâ€™d performed really well, and that he was proud of me for how consistent Iâ€™d been all year long. It was one of the nicest conversations Iâ€™ve ever had, especially because it was coming from someone I have so much respect and admiration for.

When I mentioned what was on my mind, Coach K told me that he felt like I would make a great pro, and gave a few reasons why. At one point he just said, â€œIâ€™d obviously love to have you back, but I think you gotta go for it.â€

Coach knew that I was someone who took academics very seriously, and he made it a point to say Duke University wasnâ€™t going anywhere. â€œYouâ€™ll be able to come back and get your degree later,â€ he told me. â€œYou will always be welcome here. But this is your time to show what you can do against the best in the world.â€

Coach K â€¦ he encouraged me to leave.

At a time when I was on the fence as to what I was going to do, it was actually Coach K who convinced me to make the leap.

And that right there showed me so much about Coach. It shows heâ€™s adapted. He gets it. He understands that times change. And you know what? On that day he gave me some of the best professional advice Iâ€™ve ever received.

With the 2020 draft coming up, and the deadline for underclassmen to declare right on the horizon, I felt like I wanted to try to pay it forward a bit by sharing some advice with those who are currently going through the decision-making process. And my very first tip has to do with that story I told above. Itâ€™s this: Rely heavily on the people you respect and trust most, and those who you know have your best interests in mind. Coach K was definitely one of those people for me. You need to find your inner circle and stick with those folks.

Beyond that, you have to think about your familyâ€™s economic situation, about whether your game would benefit from more college ball, and about the one thing everyone always mentions: the risk of injury. As for the rest of my thoughts and tips on the decision to leave school early, check them out below.

  • The 2020 draft is going to be unlike any other in history: Have to mention this one pretty high up, right? I mean, weâ€™re living through unprecedented times right now. Obviously basketball stuff isnâ€™t anywhere near the most important issue at this point, right in the middle of the coronavirus crisis, but whatâ€™s going on has meant that current draft prospects are in a tough situation that players like me didnâ€™t have to deal with. No individual workouts? No combine? No predraft camps? No in-person meetings? Basically your game tape is going to have to be good enough. So if youâ€™re someone who maybe didnâ€™t put up huge numbers last season, but who kills it when it comes to measurables and workouts, this honestly might not be your year.
  • Donâ€™t let something that just happened, or your emotions, dictate your decision: After we lost to Kansas in the 2018 NCAA tournament, I remember my mom and a few of my aunties came to campus to see me. We started talking about my decision, and at that point â€¦ I was totally ready to come back. I wanted to play for my school again. And win a title. But, I mean, that was literally one day after being bounced from the tourney. That was my competitive side taking over, my emotional side. You canâ€™t make a good decision that way.
  • You have to be cool with a lot of downtime: College and the NBA couldnâ€™t be more different. In college, when you wake up youâ€™ve got a roommate or housemates. Thereâ€™s almost always someone you can talk to and hang out with. In the league â€¦ some younger guys do live with someone, but for the most part a lot of people are living alone. And not everyoneâ€™s built for that. We practice maybe two hours a day, max. So there are 22 hours or so left to fill. You have to take care of your home, and find some hobbies, as well. You have to be mature. With me, I definitely underestimated the whole free time thing. At Duke, our days were scheduled from sunup to sundown. Then that all disappeared.
  • Listen to the people who know: If you know people who have direct experience with what itâ€™s like to be a professional athlete â€¦ talk to them. Learn as much as you can from those people. With me, my dad played pro ball down in the Dominican Republic. While thatâ€™s not the same as the NBA, he knew all about what being a professional athlete is like. My dad did everything in his power to make sure I knew what to expect, be it physically, emotionally â€¦ everything. He talked to me about money management, about friends, women â€” just everything imaginable that sometimes trips guys up. Those lessons have been invaluable.
  • Donâ€™t go crazy with mock drafts: I definitely looked at the online mock drafts. Itâ€™s almost impossible not to. I really tried not to fixate on them, though. More than anything, I used them to motivate me. Iâ€™d see a mock that had me going 12th or 13th, and Iâ€™d take it as a challenge. But overall I didnâ€™t get too caught up in people online guessing where I might get picked. At the end of the day, whether they have you going first or 51st â€¦ itâ€™s just a mock. Itâ€™s not real life. Beyond that, the one other thing Iâ€™ll add is that it is a bit of a different situation if youâ€™re looking at the mocks and â€¦ youâ€™re not seeing your name at all. Trying to put myself in those shoes, especially now â€” in a year when there are no individual workouts to improve your draft stock â€” youâ€™re really going to have to bet on yourself and take a leap. At the same time, though, no oneâ€™s going to believe in you unless you believe in yourself. And there are lots of guys who thought they were going to get picked, but who didnâ€™t, and who then worked their way to the NBA and had long careers anyway. But, yeah, not seeing your name at all? Thatâ€™s gotta give you something to think about for sure.
  • Donâ€™t get caught up listening to students at your school or superfans: This is a simple one. A lot of people are going to try to influence your decision, and deciding who to listen to can sometimes be tough. Other times, though, itâ€™s â€¦ not so tough. Donâ€™t let students at your school or superfans of the college influence you. Theyâ€™re not looking out for you. Period. Moving onâ€¦.
  • Prepare for people coming out of the woodwork and asking for stuff: The money that goes along with playing in the league is a blessing. Donâ€™t get me wrong. But once you declare for the draft, and people know youâ€™re heading to the NBA, youâ€™re going to start hearing from folks hoping to cash in. So be ready to deal with it. My advice is going to be the same advice that I got from veteran teammates on the Bulls when I was a rookie: â€œFind a nice way to tell people no.â€ Everyoneâ€™s way of getting that message across to folks is going to be a little bit different, but itâ€™s a must. You just have to find the way that works best for you.
  • Before making a decision, sit down for an hour or two with the people you trust the most and go through everything again: For me, this was my mom and dad, but it doesnâ€™t necessarily have to be family. Just gather the people who you count on most, and who you know will always have your back no matter what â€¦ and have a conversation where everything is laid out on the table. It may seem like youâ€™ve already gone over everything a million times. But trust me, you wonâ€™t regret having that one last conversation about it. And youâ€™ll probably remember that talk for the rest of your life.
  • After you decide, try not to second-guess yourself: This one is easier said than done, I admit. I can tell you that after I made my decision, I definitely had some regrets creep in, some second-guessing. I found myself thinking: What if I had stayed? Maybe we would have won it all? Would I have improved my draft stock? And even after I got to the league, when Duke was on TV battling it out at Cameron Indoor against UNC â€¦ Iâ€™d still be sitting there thinking, What if? But after a while you realize thereâ€™s nothing positive that can come from those thoughts. You just have to make a decision, believe in yourself, and then put all your energy into becoming the very best player you can. For me, that meant working hard so I could make my family proud. But it also amounted to me telling myself: Trust Coach K, and go prove him right.

item.title: Todd Gurley

item.description: North Carolina's finest, aka TG3, the Georgia Bulldog himself, Todd Gurley, stops in to chat with the guys
item.content:encoded: North Carolina's finest, aka TG3, the Georgia Bulldog himself, Todd Gurley, stops in to chat with the guys on this episode of Truss Levelz. Did you know that TG3 started off as a track phenom? Well, he did. Our man has speed speed. Youâ€™ll hear about him traveling the world to race. Why he nearly went to Princeton instead of Georgia â€” a move that couldâ€™ve turned him into a podcaster instead of an NFL star. The crazy time at Georgia. His ACL tear and entry to the league. And when he realized he could play his game at the highest level. We should probably mention how he drops hints at what itâ€™s like as a member of Roc Nation. Along with food and travel spots. I mean, what more do you need? TG3, now TG33 for the Atlanta Falcons, is the former Offensive Player of the Year, three-time Pro-Bowler, two-time All Pro First Team selection. Just call him Mr. Accolade. His dreads are pretty fire, too. Turn the volume up. You donâ€™t want to miss out on this one.Â

item.title: Jamal Murray
item.author: Darius Miles, Jamal Murray & Quentin Richardson
item.description: Season 5 and we poppinâ€™ off with one of the stars from the Bubble: Mr. Jamal Murray.
item.content:encoded: Season 5 and we poppinâ€™ off with one of the stars from the Bubble: Mr. Jamal Murray. The pride of Kitchener, Canada, joins Knuckleheads with Quentin Richardson and Darius Miles to go over everything, including his jump to stardom. They start off with Canada, what it was like playing ball there, how hard it was to get attention from the big-time schools and why Jamal is so proud that Canadian players are finally getting respect. Then he talks about going to Kentucky and what it was like playing under Coach Cal for a year. It was one and done and on to the draft. Jamal reveals that he didnâ€™t even work out for Denver and explains why he thought he couldâ€™ve been teamed up with Devin Booker in Phoenix. He then talks about his quiet-yet-effective start in the NBA, and what changed when he entered the Bubble this past summer. Then itâ€™s to the moon â€” Jamal discusses dropping 50 points again and again and again, what it was like going back and forth against Donovan Mitchell, and why the Nuggets felt confident even when they were down 3â€“1 â€¦ twice! Lastly, you wonâ€™t want to miss Jamal ranking his greatest Canadian players and explaining why he still doesnâ€™t own a car despite being in his fifth year in the league. A young superstar on the rise, Jamal Murray starts off Season 5 with a bang.Â
